Everything from the drinks to the food was fantastic! Chips and salSa were good. Drinks were good. We had chicken and carnitas tacos and they were delicious. Homemade tortillas made right In Front of you
Started out bad when we received the old menu with discontinued items. Waitress was less than helpful. Tempted to walk but I'm hungry.

The food here was pretty good.  I really liked how they mixed Chinese and Mexican food together on one menu, I thought that was pretty cool.  The service was good too! The only thing I really didn't like was the portion size.  I felt like it was super small for the price.  I came here with a friend and we split the Dan Dan noodles and an enchilada dish.  The food was good, but we were still hungry after we left.  I recommend the non alcoholic drink on the back of the menu ( I think it was called fresca?) it was good, but a little overpriced.

This is one of my favorite restaurants at The Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas. Gotta love the fusion of Chinese and Mexican flavors. The service is impeccable every time I go, the small plate food is fresh, delicious and flavorful! It is pricier than other places (welcome to the Las Vegas Strip!) but it's definitely worth every dollar.

I brought my mom to join me for lunch. She makes her own bomb guacamole, yet she craves the guacamole from China Poblano. You know it's gotta be good! Shout out to the hostess for being attentive when seating us, she was gracious in offering another table right away when we weren't too keen on the first (it was tight fit for us lol)

Please please PLEASE try the table side guacamole! Rumor has it the place might discontinue it, and I say keep it! The server makes the guacamole in front of you, and it was to our perfection of taste. I understand it's more difficult to offer this when it's busy, just have a dedicated person to make it on those busy days. It's such a nice touch that makes the dining experience that much more enjoyable.

Onto the food: we ordered the chips and salsa with the table side guacamole and When Pigs Fly for our main lunch items. The portions are small, they are small plates after all. But we were left quite satisfied with this. The salsa is made fresh, no heat is added so if you like spicy, let your server know! When Pigs Fly is their take on Chinese pork buns. They're Toby compared to what you get in China Town, but the flavor of the barbecue filling is to die for. Plus, the pork is leaner, not much fat which I like.

We ordered the buuelos and the mango sticky rice for dessert. These are not made in the typical fashion, so keep an open mind when ordering! I won't ruin the surprise, that's what pics are for anyway. Again, the flavors were so delicious, especially that coffee ice cream.

Samantha was our server and she's the best we've had. The food runners and bussers were on their A game, we never had empty glasses, plates were whisked away promptly and even when it was busy, they made the effort to chat a little by inquiring if everything was to our liking. Until next time!

Food lacks flavor. Portions are crazy small for the price. We got the tasting menu and they couldnt even get the time of are food out right. I'm leaving hungry and unsatisfied. Also  everything taste like it came out of a can. Service was horrible, they wiped the table while we where sitting there. They didn't refill are water. Everything was gross I had to spit some of there food.

**Vegetarian Friendly**
 
I was incredibly confused with a restaurant that serves Mexican and Chinese food (NOT a fusion restaurant), but I was incredibly surprised. They're a tapas style restaurant but their portions are larger than a normal tapas.
 
Mexican: Refried Bean Taco and Chilaquiles
The taco has salsa with a crme that blends together. A friend of mine order this too and said "I love meat but this taco is SO GOOD." The chilaquiles was a little more bland for me. The tomatillo sauce was delicious, but there was nothing else with it. So just cheese, sauce and chips. All of which was soggy by the time it came to the table, but the flavor was still great.
 
Chinese: Open Sesame Noodles
A little too soy for my taste, but it would be a great summer time dish (it's served cold). This was a more hearty dish compared to my taco, tons of vegetables. This one dish could have served 2.
 
Extra points for understanding what a vegetarian is, and having their own vegetarian menu! Overall, great prices for portions.

Are you kidding me? 

$30 for chips, guacamole, and shrimp won tons that I can make myself.

The concept is cool...to have a place with Mexican/Chinese fusion but, I can go to Carnival buffet for that.

NEXT!
Stay on the Mexican side of the menu. My Hot and sour soup was awful. Shumai and dandan noodles were ok for mall food.
Best time ever!! The food was delicious thanks to Chef Ricardo for making it a great night!! Had so much a little bit of everything on the menu. Definitely a must when in Vegas.
Way overpriced. Small portions. Service was very subpar. Waste of money in my opinion. Skip this place and hit up secret pizza instead.

Overall disappointed. The portion sizes were terrible for the price and the bartender (since we sat at the bar) failed to tell us that the dish we ordered and appetizer would not be enough for a lunch for two. We ordered the pigs on horseback due to its hype. They were definitely the best thing we had though they were on the dry side and lacked something I think a crisp vinegar style dipping sauce could have easily fixed. We also ordered the Beijing Glass noodles which promised to be a light vegetarian dish to compliment our heavy pork break appetizer. The noodles came out and the whole dish was a little larger than my fist. More of a side really. It seemed like they had marinated everything in sesame oil and had little other flavor. Since we were still hungry we ordered a couple of tacos thinking the other side of the menu would be good. Wrong. The Tinga Poblano was really flavorless and the cochinita was even worse. The pork had a bland dipped-in-A1 taste and the onions didn't add anything to the dish other than filler that distracted me from the taco. The service was terrible. Our bartender was attentive to our waters but failed to help us decide anything and generally acted aloof and a bit shady. The decor was enjoyable and the idea I think is awesome. I really hope they step their game up. Probably the worst restaurant to eat at in the cosmo. I will not be returning.

We came here prior to running the Vegas marathon thinking we could get our fill of carbs and grub on something original... Nope.

The menu is overpriced and the portions are atrociously small. It's a shame because the food is actually decent and the service was great- but come on guys, you're feeding humans. Barbie would spend a small fortune here and still leave hungry.

Skip it and head to the silver spoon buffet down the hall instead- you'll get twice the amount of food at half the cost.

Let's just get straight to the point...

Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing, but the ramen that they had there wasn't the finest I've had. It had me regretting my decision to get it and wanting the tan tan noodles that were next to me and the ceviche that was across the table. The broth was watery with some greasy in it. It was just too salty. I'll pass next time on the ramen and just get something....less complicated.

If it is authenticity you are looking for, obviously, you are setting yourself up for failure the second you step into this beautiful fusion restaurant. However, as a quintessential Angeleno, I much much more prefer fusion rather than those so-called authentic food. And China Poblano is the very reason why: it combines the distinctive taste of both worlds. Plus, it's Jos Andrs (see my reviews on "SAAM" or "Jaleo!!") 

So, after BF and I sat down, without any hesitation, we immediately ordered "China Poblano cocktail experience." On an average meal, we each can drink 2 to 4 cocktails easily, and $32 for 4 cocktails that's paired with the dishes we are about to order? Who in their right mind would've missed that?

As for food, we ordered: Langosta (seared lobster taco, I love how they served this dish out first and the grapefruit on the taco worked like an "amouse bouche" and ) Viva China (beef tendon/kumamoto oysters taco, the thinly sliced tendon was deep fried to the point like ultra thinned cristino! ) lamb pot stickers stuck on you (this is probably BF and my favorite of the entire meal; juicy minced lamb wrapped inside of dumplings that's topped with crispy fried pancake. An absolute culinary success,) Traditional Siu Mai (with edible gold on top,) Dan Dan Mian (I love how surprisingly spicy this noodle dish was,) Shrimp Mojo (my favorite second dish, not to be confused with Jaleo's garlic shrimp, the mojo sauce was actually blacken,) tres leches cake (by far the best tres leches I've ever tasted, and trust me I've tasted tons of them,) and churros (this dish was served fresh, so when I bit into the churro I can taste the exterior crunchiness as well as the soft and moist interior, not to mention they were served with a cup of hot chocolate as dipping sauce.)

China Poblano embodies attentive and friendly staffs, delicious food, drinks, and dessert, plus, modern and "fusionized" dcor. It also was the first restaurant we went to after we arrived and checked into Cosmopolitan. Thus, the impeccable dining experience at China Poblano set the bar up pretty high for the rest of this trip. If I do have to nitpick, I only wish they had more items on their menu. Please be advised this place serves "tapas style." I honestly do not think it's fair for people to give it such a low rating based on the size of the portion.

I truly hope for those who haven't experienced China Poblano's uniqueness would give it a try. As for BF and me, we cannot wait to go back to Cosmopolitan again and pay this cute place another visit!!

Had a great meal here in Jan 2012, but our return visit this year was disappointing.  No standout dishes, nothing memorable, nothing great.  Whereas the year before we walked away totally satisfied on every level, this time out was just a letdown.

Also, the bartender did nothing but try to push stuff down our throat.  I've never had such an aggressive server at any establishment, made us feel like we were being "sold to" -- at dinner!?!

That said, some clever dishes, and they serve nicely sized portions.  Perhaps we came on an off-night?  Only gave it the 2nd star due to memory of the first visit.  Proceed at your own risk.

My boyfriend and I came here after we missed the lunch window for Wicked Spoon.  We were starving (which usually allows crappy food to taste a little better) and just went for what was close.

I should have known that a Chinese/Mexican restaurant would not be a good idea.  There is a reason why I've never come across this mix.  It's because it simply does not work!  This restaurant should either focus on making better Chinese food or better Mexican, not attempt to make both types of cuisines.

I had the dan dan noodles and some soup with wontons (the name escapes me now).  The dan dan  noodles were okay.  The soup didn't have much flavor.  It's only saving grace were the wontons.

My boyfriend ordered one lobster taco (because they are $10 a pop) and two chicken tacos (mole sauce on the side).  He said the lobster taco was good, but the chicken was just whatever.

Overall, the best thing that we ordered was the guacamole and the Mexican coke.  The chips and salsa were decent.

It is my theory that all things mixed end up greater than their two parts...ever seen Halle Berry?  Exactly.

So during my last Vegas adventure, the girls and I stopped in to China Poblano...the beautiful baby of when Mexico and China do it.

The decor was cute. Not only a mix of Chinese and Mexican iconography, it was also a mix of casual and a tad more upscale. The staff was friendly and on point.  Quick with the smiles and the conversation.  But the real pride of the litter was the food.

We ordered:
Guacamole
When Pigs Fly
Beijing Glass
Tuna Ceviche
Mexican Mimosa

It was all fantastic.

First of all, the guacamole was flavorful, smooth and had enough kick to make the table of Latinas eating it nod in appreciation.
When Pigs Fly (pork buns) were fluffy and rivaled the traditional buns I've had.
Beijing Glass was zesty and refreshing.
Mexican mimosa was refreshing with just the right bitch slap of booze to make it interesting.

But they all were dwarfed by the sheer awesomeness that was the Tuna Ceviche.  There were so many textures, flavors and spices that we all could barely contain ourselves!  It was the perfect marriage of Mexican spice and Chinese textures...exactly what this place is all about.  

Next time I go to Vegas (it will be soon) I'm going back to see my little half breed one more time.

The notion of intermingling Chinese and Mexican cuisine is intriguing and exciting, and when I saw China Poblano on Yelp it seemed ideal for a late afternoon lunch. Any excuse to walk to the beautiful Cosmopolitan is actually motivation enough for me. Unfortunately, though, the restaurant ended up being an expensive, huge let down. 

My initial impressions of the interior were pleasing. The space is flavored by festive reds and other vibrant colors, exuding a playful ambiance. As I continued to make my way inside, the lack of ventilation become apparent -- extremely warm. Peeling off my sweater was a quick fix, though. After sitting down, you notice that the walls are graced by rotating projected images of Mao Tse Tung, and random images of Chinese peasant girls, little boys, and Mexican adults. It was strange.

After being seated, we were shortly met by our waiter who inquired whether or not we wanted chips and salsa. Without hesitation I said "Yes, please!". The chips were served warm in a small basket and were, admittedly, quite good. The accompanying chipotle salsa was also tasty. What I didn't realize was that the chips and salsa were $4, not complimentary as this San Diegan is accustomed to. The couple next to us had an attractive bowl of guacamole that they were noshing on. I wanted the same and requested it. Loved the flavor, but wouldn't have ordered it had I known it was $15! We quickly ran out of the small portion of chips and requested some more to have with our remaining guacamole. An additional $2 for the chips. It was my fault for not carefully reading the menu, but, seriously, I would have never expected chips and guacamole to cost $21!!! Who would?

We ordered margaritas. $13 each. Glass was very small. Do they put tequila in their margaritas? Tasted as if I was drinking straight lime juice. Gross.  

Finally, we ordered a dim sum item, the Sui Mai, a 6-piece dumpling dish ($14). Dumplings were very small and too salty for my liking. This is an item that would probably cost no more than $4 at a typical dim sum restaurant. 

After the parade of disappointments, we decided to cut our losses and treat China Poblano as an appetizer spot and move on elsewhere for dinner. Unfortunately, it was an expensive appetizer experience:  Around $70+ with tip. Overall, this restaurant just didn't live up to my expectations at all. Way overpriced for the portions you get, even by Vegas standards, in opinion.

There are some tasty things on the menu, but they're spoiled by the prices. I understand a restaurant has to make a certain amount of money for each plate, but this place was exceptionally over priced.

Tacos were good, pork buns were tasty, and the chips and salsa were ok.

Unless you're bent on going here, try another place. Quality to price ratio is out of wack.

Ok people is a fusion so don't expect the traditional taco. Also come on is LAS VEGAS off course it is over price! You can't pay your rent selling $2.00 tacos! We had several plates the flavor was ok, but i asked for cilantro and cucumber. We play around with the food (just like you do in a taco truck) and the final result was excellent . I think the restaurant should provide  extra condiments like cilantro and little servings of salsa for everyone that is part of the joy of eating tacos.
Everything was awesome and fresh. Must try their ants climbing a tree noddles and 20 veggie fried rice!!

Excellent Tacos de lengua, Baos were succulent and desert was awesome. Our waiter Kevin was top notch, super attentive and present but not overbearing. Extremely knowledgeable about the food. His description of our desert was excellent.
The outside decor is weird and we walked by wondering if this was some cheap fast food.. Almost did not go in.. but the hostesses were nice and helpful and we gave it a try and do not regret it, on the contrary.
But this level of cuisine, even if deemed simple, deserves a better decor.
Highly recommend it when you are tired of the crowds, long waiting time in the fancy restaurants. Will visit every time I come to Vegas on business.

This review is from a visit from mid-March. I had been here once before, and the food was wonderful! Unfortunately, not this time. The service left much to be desired. First, when I asked our waitress what the margaritas in the flight experience were, she referred to notes and only listed two of three, and said, "I think the third is this...". Did she go confirm? No. It was odd and LAZY. I was a little puzzled that she wouldn't go check.

One of the dishes, the "dan dan mian" was highly lackluster. No flavor, lukewarm and just bad. She came back and saw we barely touched it, but just was about to take it away without asking if anything was wrong. I interjected saying, this dish wasn't as good as the others. She responded, "Yeah...depending on the night, it's hit or miss"...

I was shocked. Does Jose Andres think his food is HIT OR MISS? I would LOVE to hear you say that with him standing in ear's length. Any chef would be highly offended of this comment. 

The kicker? She didn't take it off our bill. So we took it off her tip. 

I won't be coming back. Or to any Jose Andres restaurant. Especially if he has servers saying his food is "hit or miss". Yikes.

As we were gathering our things after touching down at McCarren airport,
our main concern was of course food.
I suggested Mexican (per usual) while my friend had been thinking Chinese. Well you can imagine our surprise when the concierge mentioned a Mexican-Chinese fusion restaurant within our very hotel.

This is not your standard Mexican. So be prepared to shell out a lot of money for
each very small taco. However, it is somewhat worth it. My friends ordered Green Tea Sour cocktails (with an edible marigold) while I tried a new beer: Moutai - it was light and exactly what I needed with my food. 

I tried the Barbacoas and Carnitas tacos. The Carnitas was quite delicious but I am not quite used to the consistency of pork belly, so it was a bit of shock to bite into something so... jelly-like. 

We ordered the Twenty-vegetable fried rice because apparently it was on some
well-known foodie list and we weren't disappointed at all.

Like all of our food, it was light, incredibly fresh and made with simple ingredients. 

For dessert I had the Mango Sticky Rice.
Coconut milk is boiled to a cream and then added to shaved mango
and sprinkled with crisped rice to create something incredible. Loved.
 
 The decor inside China Poblano was... interesting. There were steering wheels
spanning most of the ceiling, an altar of buddhas near the entrance, 
low ottoman seating and a red/orange color palette. 
 

What I loved? There is one "bar" for Mexican  and one for the Asian inspired dishes. Each were incredibly clean and each dish is served as it is ready so if you order several things (as you will need to) you do not have to place the same emphasis on some of the more traditional dining rules.
 
 While I enjoyed my experience there (for the most part...) I do not think I would go again. It is definitely a great place to pop into if you are in a bit of a rush and not 
particularly hungry, or else $6 per tiny taco just becomes a bit annoying.

I wanted some enchiladas, but I guess they didn't serve any. No problem, I'll just order something else. Bad idea... I'd be willing to compromise and say that my disliking for the restaurant was due to "denied expectations". However, recipes aside, the food was bad in basic fundamental ways that anyone could understand. We started with the Queso Fundito which was super tasty, yet it's was just melted cheese, so idk how anyone could mess it up. Speaking of which, it was literally JUST melted cheese in a small shallow saucer sized dish; why is it $11? I tried 3 different tacos, each costing $6. The carnitas was dry, the fish was rubbery, the tortillas were soggy, and the bottoms fell out. My friend ordered the "Silencio", and it looked like she was eating a taco made of arteries. I ordered some shrimp mojo for $18, and I got eight overcooked shrimp swimming in sauce. It tasted alright at first, but with each bite, the overpowering flavor was too much. It didn't taste bad; the flavor was just obnoxious, and the shrimp was rubber. It tasted like some kind of sugary tamarindo sauce mixed with chili paste but without the spice. We also ordered some other fried rice dish which look okay until the waiter plopped a sloppy runny cured egg on top. I won't say it tasted bad, but I'll say the flavor was esoteric; meaning, the taste is something not many people in Vegas are going to understand or enjoy. I'm willing to concede that the waitress did give us a small warning upon ordering, so I guess it's our fault. However, I have to ask: why have an item on the menu if your staff is going to discourage people from ordering it? The restaurant states that the dish is authentically Chinese, which I give them kudos for. However, I'm not even sure how authentic it TRULY is due to the fact that the Mexican food was ANYTHING from authentic. This honestly could just be some overpriced garbage dish being peddled out for profit. Most people in Vegas would rather NOT have a dish that looks like it's daring me to eat it, especially when the bill came to be nearly $100. I felt like I was on an episode of Fear Factor.  All of that aside, the basic fundamental ingredients in our food was disappointing to say the least. I'd rather be in LA where I can get an actual authentic Mexican taco without the dry meat or soggy tortilla for $1.50.
The food is delicious, the proficiency on  customer service needs a little more work. Overall we've had a greedy experience.
Had some potstickers and noodle dishes and they were OK.  Not bad for hotel food but would expect better in Las Vegas.
Probably the best meal I've had in years. The quail egg dimsum was absolutely delicious

Everyone's reviews are spot on. This place was only OK for me. The tacos are small. Chicken Mole Taco was gross - swimming in sauce. Fish taco smelled fishy to me - not a good sign. My friend also got extremely ill after eating here.  The chips are good, but $15 for guacamole? I can make better guac than this place. Margaritas are also about$14 a pop and are small. Like most of the cosmopolitan... this place is overpriced. I'd rather make a run for the border.

WTF Jose Andres!  I was so disappointed with this place - I feel like he just opened a restaurant with uninspired recipes he found in random places and slapped his name on it.  

There was nothing special at all going on here. Had about 7 dishes and not a single one excited me.  Definitely pass.

Walking up to this restaurant, I thought it was a Mexican and Chinese infused ingredients/food/flavor restaurant which would have been original and creative. In actuality, you can order dim sum and a taco at the same time here. 

The Mexican food was flavorful. The guac was perfect balance of cilantro and onion and avocado. The homemade salsa had some kick and their Mexican meat was tender. 

On the other hand, the sui mai I ordered was a big disappointment. It was almost to the point of raw and tiny compared to typical dim sum restaurants. I didn't like the fact that I just had guac and then took a bit of dim sum after. 

The biggest reason I'm giving this place 1 star and never coming back is the seating arrangement. The tables are about a foot away from each other and when I went, the place was near empty and the hostess still sat a group of men at the table right beside us. We were so close to them that the guy beside me flicked me with his menu turning it over on accident twice. There were empty tables behind me and behind my friend. The only excuse we got was that they like to close half the restaurant.

This place is everything can imagine for a China/Mexican fusion restaurant!! We started with the chips and salsa along with Dim Sum, sooo good!! Then we had Dan Dan Mian noodles and Mojo Shrimp!! Both were amazing but if I picked my favorite it would have to be the shrimp!!! I definitely recommend this to everyone!!

Steer clear. No bartender bad if any service. We've been coming here on every trip to Vegas. Since Brandon the bartender left it's been down hill ever since. This will be the last time I hope the ladies making the dim sum find employment. Sorry ladies

Looking at the menu was upsetting. 

I think it set the mood all wrong. 
$5 for ONE taco
$8 for FRENCH FRIES the size of an in n out fries.
$12 for a bowl of SOUP/POSOLE


Then we were like screw it we are hungry so we are just going to order. The restaurant is located in Cosmo on the second floor I believe. It's casual but pricey. Half the restaurant is Asian cuisine and the other half is Mexican. We came in cause it looked casual and the ambience was nice and colorful casual informal unlike many of the other eateries in Cosmo. 

Food was average not that great for my expectations of a $5 taco and $8 fries.
French fries were just whatever in a small basket with a mole taste like soy sauce dipping sauce. We asked for ketchup. NO KETCHUP?? But you serve fries I just don't understand. 

Soup was all right. Posole. Usually I like posole but this one was Okay. Had to add a bunch of limes. 

The Hawaiian heart of Palm salad was unique. My mom liked it cause she has never had it. 

Overall would not come back again. 
Only nice thing was that the man gave us a disclaimer that everything was tapas style. 

I love tapas but here is not the place to eat when you're hungry and want good food worth your buck.

This place is Mexican/Chinese....hence the name. It was my first time there and I really liked the atmosphere. It's very casual considering the location. It's an upscale place but at the same time you can go in with shorts/shirts. The services was great.  We had the queso fundido and had the fried wontons and they were great!! Their tortillas are hand-made!! I think the prices are reasonable. Even though I can only judge on the appetizers, I think this place is worth it.

Great concept, food is a terrible failure! Fusion done wrong!

We ordered 8 items on the menu, each one was $10-$15, tapas size. Presentation is very pretty, but the taste just lacks in flavor or texture. Tofu and avocado should not go in the same plate, duck tongue tacos were undercooked and slimy. Pear juice was super watered down. 

Jose Andres, I had high hopes. It's unfortunate. I may still try Jaleo but my visit here is not giving me much encouragement!

Was a little drunk hungry, so this should have been set up as a great experience - but we just ended up disappointed. Everything was really expensive and the portions were small. Very tasty, yes, but a rip off on cost. I've eaten at a few of Andres' restaurants, and had some amazing meals, so I'm not sure what didn't click here this time. I know he commands some higher prices, but I just didn't feel like I was getting a good value. 

On a side note, the pop culture worship of famine-era Mao on the wall juxtaposed with the $50 a person dinner struck me as a little insensitive, but then again enough time has passed since the Cultural Revolution, so, what are you gonna do?

I hate giving negative reviews but this place is just so bad.... with all the great places to eat in LV, you should skip this one. The food is not good at all, we had about 4 or 5 small things on the menu- some sort of dumplings, fries covered in toppings etc. The fries were the worst thing I eat in our 10 day trip. Also, the service was horrendous. 

I did however, get an excellent margarita

This place is an absolute gem and a must try while in Vegas! We always put this on our list of places to eat while here. The service is impeccable and the food is outstanding. We have tried over a dozen things on the menu and everything is so delicious. You won't be disappointed!

Tapas style Mexican & Chinese food (not fusion tho! They are not meshing the Asian favors with the Mexican flavors). I was recommended this place, but was iffy about trying it because it was two very different foods in the same restaurant... I wasn't sure if I'd like it, but I gave them a chance anyways and I'm so glad I did! My friend and I absolutely loved this place!!! We sat at the bar and started with an awesome pomegranate margarita topped with salted FOAM rather then the traditional salted rim. Every dish we got we were completely satisfied with and we're looking forward to our next trip back to Vegas so that we can eat here again! I highly recommend the Tuna Ceviche, Golden pig BBQ pork buns, and the mango "sticky rice" dessert.  Oh, another plus- our server was super friendly and outgoing :)

$ 4 per taco?? Jeez. The atmosphere doesnt warrant that much of a price inflation.  It is too laid back.  The wontons suck- they overcharge because they put a gold flake on them.  Tacos were good- but not $4 good. Salt air margaritas were tooo salty.

We went here at the recommendation of a friend. The concept is innovative--Chinese and Mexican. We had the hot and sour soup and a few other appetizers. I thought it was a bit too salty, very flavorful...but very salty.

I'm a Jose Andres groupie, when I started going to Jaleo in DC over 10 years ago. When I saw this was a not so expensive option for dining in LV last week, my friend and I walked right in. There was a 20 minute wait, but we were able to take a seat at the bar immediately. Had a salt air margarita which was FABULOUS. ordered a few different dishes: tacos - pancita & carnitas, noodles, something from the dim sum menu and chips with guacamole. The food was good. The ambiance was fun. The bill and the margarita were truly the highlights of the dinner. Check it out as an option for upscale fast food if you are at or near the Cosmopolitan.

Had lunch here a few days ago, started with the margarita with orange, accompanied by their chips with yummy chipotle salsa. Yes you have to pay for the chips, but this is the Cosmo so expect to pay more for everything.  Next we had the dim sum selection- so tender and light, followed by the ahi tartare with avocado chunks - so tasty!  Also tried the BBQ pork taco with marinated onions on their homemade very thin flour tortilla.  Will return here again next time in Vegas!

I was not even going to give this place a star.  The service was horrible, it took over 10 minutes for someone to approach us to take our beverage order, then it took another 10 minutes to get the drinks, which should have been our cue to leave.

We then ordered chips and salsa to start, which again took forever to get to us, then why we continued to order more was beyond me, but we did, which included the queso poblano dip, nothing exciting to write about, in addition to two very small tacos, which were ok, and then some potstickers, which my son said were horrible, and I took a bit and he was right.  Anyway, I will spare you the rest, just don't recommend going here, and we live in Vegas, and could recommend several other places that do a better job.   Very disappointed!

We ended up coming here because Holstein's was too crowded and we didn't want to wait. 

If everything here was 15% cheaper I would be giving it more stars, but the portions are really small for the price you pay. Granted, I get that it's Vegas and everything is more expensive, but I don't think the food was THAT much better than other similarly priced restaurants. 

With that said, I do think that the food was very good and I really enjoy the ambience of the restaurant. 

I was at first a little weirded out by the Chinese/Mexican combo, but in reality the dishes aren't necessarily fusion dishes but half the menu is Chinese and half is Mexican, though there are little flourishes that would make it fusion. 

There were 3 of us and we each got a taco and a main dish. My taco had mushrooms and crispy pork skin in it, which was pretty good, and I also ordered a Mexican knife shredded noodle dish which had corn truffles and mushrooms. It was very tasty. My friends also ordered the Dan Dan mien which was very similar to traditional dan dan mien at a Chinese restaurant so I didn't see any fusion aspect to it, and we also ordered the steamed buns.

Went in for lunch before we left Vegas. Started with the guacamole which is made to order at the table and it was great! The taco I had was the black bean taco with habanero and creme fresh. (Simple taco but I'm craving it already as I sit here in the airport) Had the 20 vegetable fried rice..pretty good- it's one of their more popular items but I was starting to get full at this point. My husband ordered the lamb pot stickers and whoa,  I thought they were amaze-balls. He was wanting a dipping sauce for them but I didn't think it needed it. The crispy lace design was gorgeous! My husband also got the brisket taco and the dan dan noodles. Great service!
We did the chef's tasting menu. It was really good. My only complaint is that it was too much food! Unique selections. Great for foodies.
I didn't try any of the Chinese food, the tacos were tasty but overpriced in my book. I wouldn't come here again.

i visit vegas couple time already, and this place is absolutely worst i had ever experience!!! the food quality is great, BUT the service is absolutely unacceptable!!! they bring the wrong dish to our table and took it without an apology?! Hey! Hello? and the waiters wear green shirt is a shit!!!! he start clean our table before we ask check!!! and more!! just skip this place!!!

The tacos are definitely not worth the 6 dollars or however much they are per taco. But they are pretty yummy. I got the refried bean taco and the chicken taco. The bean taco was way better! For 4 tacos and a beer, our total came to over 30 dollars. That is pretty steep.

We've been here before too. Husband ordered a taco, and we shared the chilaquiles. Those were out-of-this-world good! It's a little too much to eat alone so it's good to share.

I don't understand the mixed reviews. I actually have came twice today. First thing, if your staying in the Cosmo this is conveniently located right in front of the marquee day/night club. I had the different type of bite size tacos and thought they were amazing.  If your into spicy food, the spicy habanero sauce is no joke. I also ordered the fried rice with beef and was also amazing. Prices are average for the variety of food. After a day of partying this is the place to quickly stop and eat!

Im surprised this place is rated 3 stars. This will definitely be a returning spot for me when I visit Vegas. Dine tonight with family and it was great. Wait wasn't long. Our server Sergio was awesome. He was really detailed and attentive. He also make some delicious drinks. The house special martini (I think that's the name) with the foam salt was amazing. My sister and I order ceviche and it was bomb! The siu mai was perfect. My boyfriend order the steak and he loved it. Of course you can't forget about the chips and salsa.  This is definitely a restaurant to visit while in Vegas. Request for Sergio of course. Great service. Great food and drinks. Thanks Sergio for everything!

I go to Vegas regularly and have been to many of the great restaurants.  Though China Poblano is not as costly as some, the price for what you get is costly.  Five fifty for    one taco that I can consume In 4 bites is a little high.  Though the carnitas is delicious, it is still not worth the price.  Same can be said for the 20 vegetable fried rice.  The chicken taco was ok but not memorable.  I think the 20 vegetables was match the price.  But then again, everything is a bit more In Vegas.

This is literally the worst restaurant I've ever been to.  The tables are 9 inches tall and you have to sit on an Ottoman with your back to another guest.  I'm to distracted by the terrible ambience to even try the food.
You wouldn't think these 2 cuisines would pair together well, but it was delicious. Great place to order shared plates, I would suggest 2 per person.

We loved China Polano!!  It was perfect for our group of 4.  We thought it would be a fusion of Chinese and Latin foods, but it was pretty much split down the middle of half Chinese foods and half Latin foods.  We went for the pork, ribs and refried bean tacos (loved them all, especially the pork and bean tacos!).  Our eyes were definitely bigger than our stomachs because we also ordered the fresh guacamole and chips, beans, cheese, chips, pork bao, and the mongolian beef.  There were lots of ooos and ahhs from our table as these foods were comforting and all so tasty!  We were so impressed!  I can't wait to come back here again next time I am in Vegas!!

Dang. The Vegas crowd is harsh - or at least very conservative with their stars.  Came here over the weekend with a bachelorette party and I think everyone thoroughly enjoyed their food and drinks.

Between me and two other girls, we split: papas fritas (fries with rich mole sauce), open sesame (chilled noodle salad), Beijing glass (cellophane noodles in soup), tuna cevhiche (veeeerrrrry interesting crunch), and dan dan mien (noodles with a spicy kick).

I had a Mexican Mimosa and other people in the group had the lychee sour cocktail and blood orange margarita.

Seriously no complaints about the food except that the portions are tiny.  However, considering how many dishes we ordered for three girls (we eventually cancelled our order for 20 vegetable fried rice), I think we did just fine.  Sure, it was a little pricey, but you're in Vegas and you're at the Cosmopolitan.  The Strip is littered with Panda Expresses if you want something cheap.

Now that I've returned from Vegas, and my coworker (who recommended China Poblano to me) and I are discussing the different dishes that we've eaten here, I'm itching to go back.

I had my doubts. No reason for any of them! Service was casual, and approachable.
The food is delivered quickly and the food runners are very nice too. 

I recommend that you ask your waiter questions, share with friends and order lots of different items from both kitchens. 

Excellent - fun place to go for a fancy-casual meal.

Came back for another try and had an awesome meal.  Service is still excellent. The waiter was very knowledgeable of the menu and gave suggestions on pairing foods. I felt as though the chef was waiting on us.  The twenty vegetable fried rice is delicious. I suggest adding a protein. The shrimp mojo is a must.  Try one of their many cocktails as well!

Staff was amazing, friendly, and fun. Food was terrible - at least the things we tried. 4 of 5 tacos were either gross or bland. The queso con chorizo was SO BLAND. The salsa looked nice and homemade but was not great. Again, staff and atmosphere were nice. Food, not so much. Bill was around $60 and I would have felt comfortable paying about $12.

Very cool, hip place. As a local I always look forward to eating here. Friendly service and we has the shrimp Mojo which tasted good and the world famous crispy Carnitas tacos which are to die for! So delicious its unreal! Even the espresso was high quality. Such a cool spot, highly recommend it!
Great food and reasonably priced for being on the strip! Be sure to try the lotus chips!

One of my favorite places at Cosmo.  I usually sit at the bar and have the bartender just pick dishes for me.  Everything is pretty solid  I recommend sharing with friends and ordering a variety of things

Came here in December on a impromtu Vegas trip after the first night had a raging hangover so Chinese and Mexican sounded perfect.  I ordered a blood mary to start... ehhh it had soo much tabasco in it - it was kinda gross.  I ordered the queso fundido with chorizo and that's why i gave this place 3 stars, it was cheezy, gooey, salty and savory yumminess.  Also, ordered some tacos.. they are super tiny but have unique choices (carnitas (yum) and pork belly (ehh) I like crispy pork belly so it just tasted fatty.  I will try this place one more time to sample the Chinese part

This is an unusual and innovative restaurant. Their drinks are literally "out of this world." The food is solid and competent. The staff is helpful and friendly. Those of you who love a blend of vastly different food will love this venue.
Its fair. Feels like a dim sum style place, ie order a few menu items and share bc portions are for sharing amongst people. I would come here for tacos that seems to be the best deal here.

We came to check this restaurant out for a capstone graduation.
I was excited to try this place out it should give you the best of both 
worlds. Chinese, Mexican.. Makes me happy. 
We started with chips, salsa and guacamole.
Hmmm... If you consider some of your specialty as well mexican than your guacamole should be TOPS!!
Well it wasn't. I was pretty disappointed by the guac. I mean, The guac I make at my house is better than what I ate there. From there we also had the Sui Mai which was ok. It wasn't bad but it wasn't great either well, let me correct that.. the scallop Sui Mai was GREAT.... the traditional shrimp/pork.. well not so much! 
We did try the twenty vegetable fried rice which was good. Probably the best thing on the table for me. 
I also had the fish taco which was good. 
Overall the food was good/ok for the price, I would expect better tasting food. I just wasn't overly impressed I guess..

Some food was great and some of the food was just ok.
The fried rice is good.
The dim sum was great!
Tacos were good.
Service was ok.
Overall good,
I'll go back again to try a few other items.

China Poblano is one of my favorite casual restaurants on the Strip. One plus is that for smaller groups or going solo, you usually won't need to wait long if at all for a table - and can always eat at the bar too. They also have a window for takeout orders.

First off, must get this out of the way:  This is NOT a fusion restaurant - they have Chinese small bites / street food and Mexican small bites / street food, served independently. This is pretty clear even from the restaurant's website and I don't at all get why people expect differently and then rate this place poorly for it.

My go-to dishes are the tableside guac (strongly recommend tortillas), twenty vegetable fried rice, lamb pot stickers, and the silencio, cochinita, and lengua tacos. The chilaquiles, "gan pung ji" chicken, and dan dan mian are all solid dishes and worth ordering if you're a fan of them generally, but not particularly outstanding.

Based solely on the food, this place is a pretty easy 5* but the service is rough sometimes (the waiters/waitresses are all usually friendly enough, but are often inattentive / slow to get things done). Similarly, when the place is busy, the cooking stations can get really backed up and the dishes take forever to come out (on a recent trip, the wok station was backed up and several of our wok dishes like the fried rice took nearly an hour to be prepared).

Food was descent, BUT very...very...small portions. 
Dan Dan Noodles (taste = 4 Stars) super small portion.  Noodles tasted fresh and looked handmade.  However for $14, I expected more than 5 bites.  Even for Vegas)
Steamed Shui Mai, (taste = 4 Stars)
Chicken Taco (taste = 3.5 Stars)

This is not a fusion of Chinese and Mexican.  Different cooks cooking, so all your food does not come out at the same time.  

There are plenty of choices in Vegas, as I waited for my food and watched my friends eat w/o me, I started to think that should have waited in the line 2 doors over at EggSlut.
Was very good...had a little of everything...only giving 4 stars because it wasn't as GREAT as I was expecting from Jose Andres...but it was tasty and reasonably priced.

Great restaurant that combines two of my favorite food groups - tacos and noodles! We sat at the taco bar and watched mesmerized as they made fresh corn tortillas. Of course we had to try them and the tacos were delicious as well as the Ants Climbing a Tree noodles. 

The restaurant was mostly empty on a Tuesday evening so service staff was very attentive. Also don't skip the drinks - the Salt Air Marg is definitely one of the better margaritas I've had.

My husband and i stayed at the Cosmopolitan a few weeks ago. While there we had dinner here. It was fantastic. The food was very different so we were a little nervous. The server took his time to carefully explain and recommend a few things to us. We took his advice and ordered a few things that we would have never otherwise ordered. His suggestions were dead on! Everything we tried was delicious.

This restaurant was Delish!  We ordered tacos and chicken fried rice.  Service was attentive and friendly.  The fried rice is definitely meant to be shared.  It came in a bowl and was more then enough for 2 people (3-4 people would be good).  Tacos were a little pricey though.  $5.50 each.  Since it is vegas we let that slide.  

We would definitely come back.

I would give China Poblano five stars except that on our second visit the service wasn't as good as our first visit. We loved the food so much we ate there twice during our weekend trip to Vegas.  The first visit was great. The service was exceptional.  The food is remarkable. Chef Andres' concept is so great. My two favorite food genres together in one restaurant! One word "brilliant".  Every item we ate was great. Here is the list of foods we tried on both visits. No complaints. Cochinita Taco, Barbacoa de Res Taco, Carnitas Taco,  Dan Dan Mian noodles, and from the Dim Sum menu  Lamb Pot Stickers Stuck on You, When Pigs Fly, and Golden Pigs. My absolute favorite thing was the Don't Be Jealous (hot and sour soup). The soup was so yummy. On our second visit the server forgot my husband's drink order and one of his taco orders. We were charged for the taco but the manager took it off the bill. Overall China Poblano is a good restaurant; I just think they need to work on their service.

I know this is some award winning Chinese/Mexican fusion but I left hungry and unimpressed. The waiter told us the portions where small and the menu is set up to do more tapas style. That is great but when small plates are $20+ it gets expensive fast. Now had the food knocked me off my feet I'd make concessions for the Vegas resort prices. Unfortunately there where no fire works. My family and I tried both Mexican and Chinese fare but all agreed it left something to be desired. The decor and service where excellent but I felt the food did not live up to the hype.

The trickiest part of this Chinese/Mexican fusion idea is that as much as the Chinese dishes sound interesting, hold back your temptation and just get their tacos. Open up your mind and tastebuds to eat like a real Chinese person, AKA not to say eww at everything. 

Came here three times (2012, and twice in 2015). I'm going to ignore 2012 because that was when anything edible was good. Part 1 of 2015 was after hearing good things about this place from a friend for decently priced meal. Ended up getting the Beijing Glass, which is like a cellophane noodle salad that looks like a bibimbap, and a side order of Viva China taco, raw oyster taco. Noodle was basically a disappointment, bland, took too much work to chew or pick up. The taco however was packed with various tastes and textures. You have this soft taco shell with a thin crispy beef tendon, and this piece of Kumamoto oyster that's on the sweeter end and not meaty. It's a good 3-4 bite of surf and turf.

Came back another time and only got 3 tacos and split the Siu Mai sampler. Had to go back to my Viva China, discovered my new favorite: Silencio (duck tongue and lychee, sweet and savory), and Pancita al Pastor (pork belly, pineapple). The pork belly one was tender, but not too memorable. For those who are hesitating to try the Silencio, if you can eat lengua, it's just more chewy in texture. The sauce is similar to the one you eat with Peking Duck, the lychee is just a refreshing component to throw your taste buds out of the box. Fusion does work when it comes to Asiany tacos! Yes, the tacos are pricey, but how often do you find some fascinating combination of ingredients? Siu mai sampler was a disappointment, the dumplings were fairly small, traditional one wasn't even as good as your local dim sum restaurant's, the best one was the scallop. The thrill and enjoyment of that 1/3 good dumplings wasn't just as luck as they were called on the menu....

At first I was hesitant to try this place because I am not really a big fan of Mexican food, but this place surprised me. Combining chinese and Mexican food is a wow. Most of the food made authentic. The traditional Siomai was my favorite. They actually put gold on top. It was pretty good.They have weird names of soup but oh my god, taste so good. The dessert is also amazing, my favorite is the sticky rice with mango but with a twist. This place really surprised their customers. They are very creative. They have good customer service and they are ready to help you with your questions and orders. The place is Beside marquee. They have a comfortable lounge outside while waiting for your seAt and table. The service is fast and the food is incomparable. I will come back here and I will recommend this to my friends.

Get ready for the most rushed dining experience of your life! At one point, while I was biting into a taco, I had a server reach over my head to grab a plate. Really, guy? 

The food here is total bullshit. $5.50 gets you one taco, with a dry factory made tortilla, some dry meat, and here's the showstopper - pickled onions. Boom. Gourmet. Dude, I've had better tacos at some of the most ghetto taquerias and the price was nothing close to $5 fucking fifty. Get a grip. Oh yeah, it's Vegas. Boom. Roasted.

We dined here before heading to Marquee and I'm almost positive the outcome would've been more satisfactory had we gone anywhere else. Price and portion aside, the food wasn't that good. The shu mai making skills of the expressionless Chinese women in the open kitchen was extremely robotic, but it was really interesting to watch. They've reached the highest peak of their mastery of dumplings and now they look bored. There was no interaction between the cooks and bar occupants. At least you can confirm the food's authentic.

My bf and I wanted to taste a couple to start so we ordered 3 items and the couple with us went crazy and ordered 10. They gave my plate to them which ended up sitting on the side with their other 5 plates and so mine got cold before they corrected the mistake. That was also realized only after I inquired the whereabouts of my shu mai. The waitress was going to set my food down, then was stopped in her tracks by a manager(?) who ended up swapping the dish with our friend and then I finally ended up with my plate...which was now missing a dumpling. It's not a big deal since it was our friend who ate a shu mai thinking it was hers but I can't believe that's how the staff handled it. Anyway, the dish fell flat for me. I wouldn't have been able to tell the difference eating supermarket frozen shu mai. My bf ordered an expensive taco and ceviche that was pretty good but any slightly positive thought of the food was overshadowed by the bill and my still empty stomach. We could get this food better at any block in Santa Ana. It would be ridiculous to spend a hundred bucks on mediocre food just to get full. At the end, we decided to cut our losses and not order anymore. They did succeed at visual appeal because the place looked incredible.

Exceptional customer service and impeccable fusions of flavor and culture. I would recommend this establishment to all and would challenge them to step out of the box and let the wait staff suggest the day away. The wine list is amazing, although I wish there was a draft system, however, I can live with the bottle selection. Cheers!

Everything started off good with half of our order coming in decent time.  Then things went downhill fast.  Water empty.  No server checking on us. 15 minutes and still no chicken tacos.  Found the waiter and he said he would "check on it".  Returned and said they would be out in a minute. 5 minutes later no tacos.  Had enough and asked for the check.  The manager brought the check and said nothing.  I asked him why such bad service and he said some food is much slower than other food.  But Chicken tacos??  Then he tells me "I took the tacos off your bill". Like the ones that never showed up!   Gee thanks.  Nothing but a tourist trap!

China Poblano was a win with me. However, the $80 bill for 2 people who ordered 4 little plates of food and 2 beers was not completely winning with me. 

Ok, I understand, you pay for the name. Jose Andres is a brilliant chef. The idea of mixing Mexican food and Chinese food is ingenious. 

The food was good, the service was great. the Rou Jia Mo Street Sandwich with red braised pork was super delicious. The When Pigs Fly were Bao buns filled with pork. Although they were good, I have had better for way cheaper in Chinatown. We had a Barbacoa de Res taco and Pancita al Pastor taco. Both were good but keep in mind you are paying $5 for one small sized "street taco."

I m still rating it 4 stars because the atmosphere was fun and the service was great. The servers really take the time to explain the menu. If I go back, I would like to try one of the many "smoking" drinks I saw getting passed around. 

Great concept but do not expect street food prices.

Mehhh not the greatest. Also, pricey af. I guess that's what I get for eating here at the Cosmo. 

First of all, let's talk about their kitchen set up. Apparently there are FOUR diff kitchens that your food can come out of, depending on what you order. Let me tell you how the table next to us left US feeling SUPER awk. I mean, not their fault. The wife got her food. They got their shared food. Then the hubbys food...never came. Well, actually, it did...only 25mins after the wife finished her salad?? They were pissed. And frigid to the wait staff. Who did try their best to apologize. Multiple times. But really, nothing would get them to budge or lighten the mood. And these tables set up are RIGHT next to each other. Their bad mood was spilling into our table. 

But anyways, it did take a while for all our foods to come. Nothing comparable to the neighbors experience. I meannn, at the end of the day, it's really not the wait staffs fault. It's the operations and kitchens tbh. It's a strange set up. I get it. You're trying to be interesting and unique...but it's not being optimized to its full potential. 

ALSO. Aside frm the set-up and staff, the foods just not very good. Every single dish was over-vinegared. The bud and I thought it was super strange. I understand that you're trying to do a china-mex thing, but it just didn't taste very good. And you're charging $20 per dish!! After tip and tax, I paid almost $72 for just my portion...pretty ridiculous. My dishes were the shrimp mojo (main), woodear fungus (side), glass noodles (shared), and ceviche (shared app). The seafood was very fresh, but the flavors were strange!! Too much vinegar ahh. 

Okay, overall, 2.5 stars, but I'll round up to 3...
small portions. crazy small portions. stick to the buffet because at china poblano, the  food didn't taste very good. and it was grossly overpriced. i will never return. NEVER! EVER. EVER!

It's a really cool concept - the decor is really cool also - HOWEVER;
food is just mediocre, and prices are steep for extremely small bites.

Boyfriend and I made our way here after the Marquee Dayclub, so take that as you please on my tastebud judgements. 

We were starving but knew we had a dinner to get to later with his family so we came for mostly a snack to hold us over. We ordered:

- Traditional Siu Mai
- Carnitas Taco
- Swallow a Cloud

I wish we could have ordered more to try other things because I was super happy with what we got. 

Traditional Siu Mai doesn't taste all traditional like you would get at a real dim sum place, but it was still pretty good in its own Vegas Chinese Mexican restaurant type of way. 

Carnitas Taco....bf and I cheers with the chicharron they put on top and enjoyed a pretty delicious taco with an awesome salsa verde. But $6 for one taco hurts the heart a little bit. But what can you do...it's Vegas. 

Swallow a Cloud (wonton soup basically) kind of surprised me. I didn't have high expectations for it and just thought it was going to be a salty mess. Wontons were flavorful, broth wasn't too salty and noodles were just right and not too soggy. But of course $16 is pretty rough to pay for a small portion of soup. 

Overall, pretty good dining experience. Service was friendly, but didn't refill on my water often. Food was delicious, but definitely overpriced. But because it's Vegas, I'd probably end up back here again the next time I'm in town.

The Chinese-Mex concept is def interesting, but I agree with reviewers before me in that the food did not necessarily live up to expectation. Which is not to say that it was bad... just that there wasn't anything of note.

My hot & sour soup was neither particularly spicy nor sour... but it was noticeably oily and somewhat lacking in traditional seasonings. 

On top of that, the food was overpriced for the portion sizes... if anything, the only thing I could say that was good about the price was that they decided to be cute with the Chinese side of the menu and make things $X.88 ... i.e. my soup was $8.88 --- my friend's dish was $12.88 ...  for those not in the know, 8 is a lucky # in Chinese culture... so - good try to be "in touch" and cute, but maybe knock down that first # by a few digits and then we can try to be friends.

Really unique combo, Mexican food and Chinese food, served together. The decor is very weird but fitting. We tried out about 12 different menu items and they were all pretty good, maybe not quite worth the decent price tag, but good nonetheless. The waitstaff was very attentive and overall service was very good.

There's no Mexican-Asian fusion going on in this restaurant, except that the 2 menus and decor are intertwined. It's almost like someone could not decide if they wanted to open a Mexican restaurant or Chinese restaurant, so they decide to open both in the same space, with separate kitchens. I love both Mexican food and Chinese food, but this is neither here nor there. Two cuisines that are normally best in a hole-in-the wall spot, and inexpensive - this is just the opposite: overpriced and mediocre.

We ordered everything family style and tried to get a good mix of both Mexican & Chinese food:

Blood Orange Chile Pequin Margarita ($15) - I liked this margarita a lot. I don't care for the taste of tequila, and the blood orange seemed to mask this well. It had a spicy kick to it, but not so spicy that it was undrinkable.

Guacamole & Chips ($15) - Handmade, and delicious, but the price is about double what I would expect to pay for fresh guacamole. Chips were light, crispy and fresh.

Tacos (about $5 each) - I'm used to dollar tacos (maybe $2) at a taco truck. I got the Tinga Poblana and it was good, but unless I'm expensing my meal to work, I would pass on this - much too expensive for tacos.

Lamb Potstickers Stuck on You ($12.88) - 6 pieces - This was probably one of my favorite dishes of the night. The lamb inside was tasty and I liked the crispy lace (sweet onions) design on the dish. Would recommend this.

Sui Mai ($13.88) - 6 pieces - The only cool thing about this were the gold flakes on top. The rest was just okay, and tasted heavy on the ginger. At a normal dim sum restaurant, you can get 4 sui mai's for $4 that taste better.

Dan Dan Mian ($12) - Wheat noodles and spicy pork sauce - This was definitely spicy, nothing that blew me away though. At least the price was reasonable for the portion-size.

Col de Bruselas ($12) - These are on the acidic side - tasted really limey. I wouldn't get this again.

Shrimp Mojo ($18) - 8 pieces of shrimp = $2.25 per piece of shrimp. Sauce was good, not too spicy, this was one of the better dishes we had.

Bistec con Mole Amarillo y Hongos ($20) - Grilled hanger steak with mole - there were about 6 sliced pieces of steak - again, with the small portions. It was one of the better tasting dishes we had, but expensive.

All in all, it's an interesting concept and I was there for work so I was able to expense my meal. With tip and tax, it was $60 per person - quite honestly, I would rather eat at a Mexican food truck or a hole-in-the-wall Chinese place for 1/4 of the price and more authentic food. With so many other options in Vegas, I'll be going elsewhere.

I really wanted to like this place because we were starving and seriously craving some Asian noodles after a night of drinking. We came down here to eat after we couldn't handle Marquee Day Club anymore.

The three of us ordered the dan dan mien, wonton noodle soup and the beef lettuce dish to share. My favorite was the beef lettuce dish, only because the other two were  disappointing. Portions were pretty small overall, sadly. I really wanted soup, and the broth in the noodle soup was bland, but the wontons were yummy! There were barely any egg noodles.

The chewiness of the dan dan mien was perfect though! And the service was exceptional too. I also enjoyed the restaurant decor because it was really fun and cute, and loved the wallpaper and Asian style decorations.

The food is OK, pretty overpriced, but the restaurant is fun and the service is great. It's really a toss up since this seems to be one of the only Asian restaurants at the Cosmopolitan.

As a concept, China Poblano is classic Jose Andres. The tapas-style menu is perfect for groups and a good selection of Mexican street food and Cantonese dim sum staples will offer something for everyone. However once price comes into the equation, things get a little worrying.

China Poblano does a few things very well. It's hip, casual atmosphere is right at home at the Cosmopolitan and the quick service and sharing nature of the food make it a good lunch spot. 

The Good: China Poblano's tacos are easily the highlight of the menu. The braised beef barbacoa and chicken with chorizo are delicious options, but keep in mind they are quite small. The chilaquiles are another highlight with a bright tomatillo salsa and lots of melted cheese. The service was fast and friendly and the waitstaff were good about explaining each dish.

The Bad: For as good as their Mexican options are, China Poblano struggles more with the Chinese side of the menu. The Mongolian beef salad was described as lettuce wraps on the menu, only when it arrived we discovered that wasn't the case. The beef came laden with a corn syrup sheen found only at the very best bad Chinese spots and it was very tough to chew. The restaurant's prices are high, too high for what you're getting. China Poblano is clearly catered towards to street food crowd and over $6 for a taco (2-3 bites) is too much.

Andres is doing great things for gastronomy throughout the world and while the Mexican food at China Poblano is excellent, you pay a bit too much for the Andres stamp of approval.

Chinese and Mexican. Two of my favorites cuisines and we were starving so we thought there was no way China Pablano can mess this up. In addition, the burger place next door, Holsteins, is DELICIOUS and we've eaten there a few times so we thought we'd give this place a try.

The two of us wanted to sit next to each other, but the host would not let us. Apparently, all tables with adjacent seats were reserved. This place was only 30% full. When sat down, we sat next to each other anyway so a different host came and apologized, and pushed together another table for us so that we are more comfortable. Meh, whatever. 

We ordered When Pigs Fly, Barbacoa de Res, Don't Be Jealous, and a quesadilla off their "specials" menu. Also, a $6 bottle of a small non-refillable coke. Rip-off. When we got our food, they came one at a time so it was more like eating a bunch of appetizers. Which didn't bother me too much, but it bothered my boyfriend that he couldn't try a bite of each at a time, but instead was forced to finish one plate at a time. We had to send back Don't Be Jealous, a hot and sour soup. It had a thick layer of sesame oil and simply put, it just tasted like crap. They took it off the check so props for that.  The rest of the food was just meh. The Barbacoa de Res was $5.50 for ONE taco. Literally. It came wrapped with ONE corn tortilla so of course, as soon as I picked it up, it split in half and just fell all over the place. I've had better $1 street tacos. The When Pigs Fly was a microwaved dumpling. I can tell because I'm Asian. How disappointing. The filling was just bland sauce. The quesadilla was the best out of the 4 dishes and even that I could have made a better one at home, and it was 4 bites for $12. Let me just say that we don't mind paying stupid amounts of $$ for small plates, as long as they taste good. 

Wow. We were so upset that we didn't just go to Holsteins instead. Bad even for a strip restaurant. As a local, I hope this review will help others avoid this tourist trap restaurant.

I loved this place! Yeah it is on the pricey side but you're on the Vegas strip what do you expect??? 

I loved the salt foam cloud margarita! I did try the flaka one but it wasn't awesome. The server happily exchanged it for another salt foam. 

The carnitas taco and veggie fried rice were definitely my favorite things we tried. Service was good both times we dined and will probably make it a tradition to return each time we go. Can't wait to try the other Jose Andres restaurants in Vegas next time as well!
Nice concept and good food! The employees were very friendly. The tasting menu is pretty good even though it is served quite fast. Salt air Margarita is something to try!

My husband and visited China Poblano at the Cosmopolitan during our last stay in Las Vegas. The wait for food is long, no matter the order. The service is fair and the food was a disappointment. We had the Mexican options...various street tacos. They were a) pricey for small street tacos; b) the chicken was just maybe cooked, with some pieces bordering raw. I had to spit out two pieces of under cooked meat; c) a beer and simple Corona and Diet Coke cost $13. You are paying here for location and the brand name of a famous chef. The only redeeming thing was the great salsa.
This restaurant is very unique concept! Chinese and Mexican food are together   Food is Little over price but of course right ... it inside hotel ! all stuff was very kind and friendly.

I've reviewed it before, and I returned a year later, only to review it again: This place is amazing. I love the Mexican dishes much more than the Chinese, but the service, food and margaritas are all first class. You MUST have the carnitas taco with verde sauce --I could eat these all day. The tortillas are homemade here. The salsas are perfect. The margaritas are fresh with no mixes or syrups. I love it so much I ate there twice this week. You will too.
Seriously how is this place still open?  The service is horrible, personnel are rude and the food is terrible.  Jo?e please check your place out and change something.

Corrine was our server she was very friendly I found this place on yelp as we are looking for something to eat nearby.   It's a little pricey but you're at the cosmopolitan what do you expect the food and service were both great so I thought it deserved a Yelp

Food was good (both the Asian and Mexican dishes we had), but the small portions in conjunction with the high prices mean that I won't be going back.

I also agree with those saying this is not considered Fusion really.  I was expecting something more like Chino Bandido (an asian/mexican fusion place in Arizona) or something like that.

I am so disappointed with the food at this place. I ordered the carnitas and seta tacos and a side order of brussel sprouts.

Everything was just drenched in oil and I'm pretty sure there was more of that than any other ingredient in my plate. I've been here two different times and its been exactly the same. Sorry China Poblano - I don't see what the hype is about.

THIS PLACE WAS A MAJOR LET DOWN!!! Over priced flavorless Dim Sum( and I've had some shitty Dim Sum in my life) The portions were very pricey and minuscule. I could tell the server knew I didn't like my food and then she proceeded to avoid my table out of fear I guess. Either way don't go here unless you don't mind wasting time and taste buds.

I honestly would not recommend unless it's the only option you got. To start, I'm always wary of Asian fusion restaurants but this wasn't fusion of anything at all. The menu provided you either Chinese food or Mexican food - which, mind you is completely fine but neither of the options are that great. Taking a look at the menu you'll see that for dim sum items that you could get for $5.00 at ANY authentic Chinese restaurant has been surcharged to ridiculous prices. 

The service is alright too, most food came out fairly quickly except for my colleague's entree. We had to flag down the server twice to check on her food and only after the second time did she mention that the specific entree my colleague placed does take quite some time. I feel like this is worthy information  that should have been provided in the beginning. 


Overall, I wasn't very impressed and there are too many good options out in Vegas for you to waste you time here.

I was so disappointed when I got my "sticky rice with mango". It was the saddest version of it that I've ever had. It was basically a few chunks of mango, whipped cream and rice crispy cereal. Total rip off.

The concept is fancy but the flavor, lacking.

Ordered quite a few dishes here to share between 3 people, but nothing stood out that made me want to try again next time I'm in town. The best of the dishes were on the Mexican side of the menu...all the different tacos are average to above average.

Noodles - you automatically want to try the hand pulled noodles right away because theres always fresh noodles being pulled by the chef in the front of the restaurant. However, the dan dan noodles we tried was soggy, no texture and over cooked. ARgh, what a disappointment.

Buns - tasted like it was reheated from the frozen varieties.

Is it too harsh to say the next best thing to order was the Mexican Coke !!?!

As far as Chinese food goes, they're making an effort. There's the "kitchen" in front that you can watch through a window from outside as a few chefs who given their appearance are most likely direct Chinese imports, acquired to boost authenticity both visually and gustatorially. There is the real kitchen that you don't see though, and most likely all the food that isn't a steamed bun is created back there by who knows who.

Fitting the Cosmopolitan Hotel, the digs are stylish and interesting and modern. Service is excellent and the menu has great variety, but prices are steep. I was surprised to see that they had rou jia mou on the menu, being somewhat obscure here in the United States to the average person, but I didn't order it. My friend did, and my initial reservation about the price to size assessment were correct. A typical rou jia mou is something like sauced pork in a flatbread sandwich about five inches in diameter (to simplify the explanation). This one was sized accurately and slipped into a protective waxed paper pocket to keep fingers clean. $8.88 is much too steep for such a "snack," even in the somewhat stylish surroundings. The meat in the rou jia mou had the same shortcomings that I've seen in other restaurants in the same dish and in beef rolls. The sauce is correct, but the meat is flavorless-if it is done properly, the sauce flavor permeates the meat instead of just covering it.

I had the dan dan mian, the noodles being very good, but the sauce had no kick, no spice. That seemed to be a re-occuring theme throughout our table's dishes- weak flavor.

I'm tempted to return simply because I hadn't explored the Mexican side of the menu, especially because that is one thing that this country does "right" more often, but my reservations continue to be about price. Perhaps if I'm in the casino again and flush with winnings, I'll return. Otherwise, there's much more culinary turf to explore in the city.
good food and service. Too expensive for the plate size

I was a little apprehensive about trying this place because of the mixed reviews and the prices... 

We deliberated for a little while, but decided to try with the knowledge that 1) This is not really a fusion place and 2) We probably weren't going to be full.

The place is decorated really cute and fun and the service is very friendly and attentive. I ordered the wild mushroom taco, the 20-vegetable fried rice, and the Open Sesame cold noodles. My companions ordered the lotus chips, Lengua taco, some kind of taco with oyster, and Pozole Rojo.

That wild mushroom taco was so delicious!!!! I have never had anything like it. Priced at $5.50, it is rather expensive for a teeny tiny taco but I LOVED it and that makes it totally worth it. I thought that the noodles and fried rice were also pricey, but really good and surprisingly filling. Try counting 20 vegetables in the fried rice... try it! J really enjoyed the pozole. I'm sure he wished it came in a larger portion too. The lotus chips were thin and crispy, not greasy at all.

So in conclusion, it's no lie that this place is super expensive. However, I still think it is worth the splurge because in the end, if the food and dining experience can exceed my expectations, then I am glad that I tried it. Trust me, I have paid close to the same dollar amount for sub-par food and service.

This place is soooo yummy. Good for the herbivore & the omnivore together ;) where everyone is happy. Yay. They made the guacamole in front of you to your taste! So awesome. Lol everyone loves guac & if you don't ...I can't trust you. Hahah I've ate here a few times for take out and then finally dined in yesterday and it was so nice to eat there. Super chill vibe & the decor was funky different. I loved it. Really artsy. :) my friend was more than pleased with all his food and I was happy with my mushroom tacos & that habanero salsa is to die for lol so if you go there get it ! But it's pretty hot , just a warning. I love really spicy so I'm happy with it :p I would recommend poblanos to everyone. It's delicious & it's not crazy priced.

Huge rip off. Nickel and dime you for everything g. I had the veggie dim sum (was decent) and glass noodles. I asked for tofu in the noodles (they don't have tofu in anything). The noodles were a basically a salad with chopped up RAW tofu served to be on a side plate. Stay away.

Go check out Jaleo instead!  The food was terrible, and not really a mix of the 2 cultures, but rather, just serving individual Chinese and Mexican dishes.  The service was not very attentive and very slow.  Won't find me there again.

China Poblano is such a waste of money. DO NOT COME HERE! As I was walking through Cosmopolitan, I didn't really pay much attention to this little Asian-Mexican joint because it looked like an unappetizing fast food spot, BUT what did catch my eye was Jose Andres' name plastered in front of the restaurant.  I've fallen in love with Jose Andres ever since my enjoyable experience at The Bazzar so I just had to try it.  Of course I knew it wasn't going to be the same, but this just wasn't even good... for any type of standard.  I wanted to try an item from both sides so I opted for the lobster taco and their dan dan mian noodles.  The lobster taco was about $10 and the noodles were around $16?  Both were extremely overpriced for what I got and I honestly don't mind forking out the cash for good food, but this did not even come close.  The portions were extremely small for both, not to mention that my lobster taco was soggy.  The dan dan mian noodles were supposed to be one of their more popular items and I can tell you that there are about a million places in 626 that do it better for about $6.  I regret coming here and should've just gone to Secret Pizza.  China Poblano, how dare you taint Jose Andres' reputation like that!!

Food tastes good, but the portion is pretty small. Everything is about half of the portion of what we were expecting, more of appetizer size if not less. 

Would not recommend if you are slightly hungry.

I was there recently with a few of my foodie friends in media. We met the leadership team and chef. Surprisingly authentic dim sum. Love me some Shu Mai! The oyster on crackers with XO sauce was insanely great. The mix drinks there were bold, sweet and refreshing with every sip. Wonderful to see the noodles were hand cut by the chef. What a super cool, hip decor, with innovated food that is a hybrid of Mexican and Chinese. Give it a try!

Who would of thought that they would offer Chinese and Mexican food in the same restaurant. This isn't your typical chain Chinese restaurant. The food was very authentic and the service was great. Just go ready to share as plates come in tapa like portions.

Jose always gets five stars. Only had two dim sums but both were excellent. The mezcal margarita with chili salt was also excellent - equivalent to a margarita in Mexico City. Ambience was also on point with large portraits of Mao and Frida.

2.5 stars

Unfortunately, I was ultimately disappointed.  The service was actually quite excellent, but the food ultimately fell short, considering the price.  

It was interesting to see that in the front of house, there were two kitchens.  A Mexican kitchen and a Chinese kitchen on opposite ends.  I was hoping for more fusion entres, but there were only a few.  The menu was predominantly Mexican or Chinese.  

Setas Tacos: Mushroom tacos.  Nothing special.  It felt it needed some kind of fresh vegetable in there to add some crunch.

Twenty-Vegetable Fried Rice: Actually pretty good with an amazing variety of vegetables in it.  Good flavors, season well.  Is it worth paying $16 for fried rice...however good it may be?  Questionable.

The Unruly Monk: Hand-cut noodle soup.  When it came out, it smelled absolutely amazing and then it went downhill from there.  The hand-cut noodles were overcooked and mushy.  The broth lacked flavor.

Beijing Glass: My friend had this one.  It actually had a nice crunch and was refreshing.  I'd call this dish a success.

Guacamole: This was really good guacamole with just a hint of heat.  But $12 for only one cup of guac????  C'mon...that's crazy talk. 

Papas Fritas with XO Sauce: Interesting concept, but WOW...that XO sauce is extremely overpowering and extremely greasy.  I had about 4 fries, but after that, it was too much.
