Neither of these things exist at this restaurant which led me to ponder whether Mr. Andres had ever visited his own restaurant to sample some of the food here. 

This restaurant features a unique idea of combining Mexican and Chinese dishes existing in tandem on the same menu. Unfortunately this fresh take on offering two different cuisines on one menu does not materialize on the plate. We ordered a variety of dishes from both the Mexican menu and the Chinese menu starting  with Guacamole which was so heavily seasoned with lime juice as to make it off-putting and unappealing. The pork belly and pineapple taco, served in a flimsy and very small tortilla (5" diameter), was layered with one tiny shaving of pineapple so thin you could read through it and an equally thin shaving of pork belly with a dab of red sauce and a shred of lettuce. I could go on and on about the equally disappointing Chinese dishes we ordered but I'll spare the reader. As a final word, I've had better Chinese food from my local strip-mall Chinese take-out joint for 75% less money. My advise: avoid this place. The quality of the food is poor and grossly overpriced. There are other wonderful restaurants in the Cosmopolitan to enjoy.

I recommend this place for fresh made food. I have ocean nest and golden bun. The dry seafood noodle was so delicious and crispy but the gold bun with the bbq pork was too sweet but it wasn't  bad. I love the chip & salsa too. Great place great atmosphere!

Food: Pozole, MOJO Shrimp, and can't remember the rest. There were 5 meals.
Everything was delicious. Very tangy. Don't know if there's a fusion between Chinese and Mexican food. Dishes were either Mexican or Chinese. Make sure you ask for lime for the MOJO Shrimp. The flavor sky rockets! 

Service: The team was very attentive.

Environment: Clean. It felt more Asian than Mexican themed.

Verdict: Highly recommended. I'll be back next time I'm in Las Vegas.

When you're Hungry... and I mean HUNGRAY! Give this combo Asian and Mexican fusion a try. I was pleasantly surprised. I Will Most Def Go Back... and the cute bartender extraordinaire Sarah is an Amazing and well trained specialist. She'll Hook You UP!

Spent our 24th anniversary at China Poblano and we were so, so satisfied.  But be warned this is a trendy "small plate" big price restaurant which means both your wallet and your stomach could be left empty. However, the food is delicious, the atmosphere fun and the service impeccable, if a bit pretentious (each food runner describes the dish you just ordered as they deliver it to your table in case you are so drunk on their incredible tequila offerings that you need reminding). 

China Poblano offers both Mexican and Chinese dishes side by side, hence the name.  I was hoping for more of a fusion concept but dove in with all tastebuds firing. 

Number one: Get the carnitas taco.  At $5.50 it is moist, flavorful and meaty!  Yes there should be at least 2 if not 3 tacos for that price but trust me, ignore the price and just order a lot of these! 

The guacamole and warm tortillas are delicious and filling.  The quail egg shumai are great and you get 6 of them in one order.  The pozole is good and satisfying, not the best I've had but good.  The dan dan noodles were earthy tasting and not my favorite although the actual noodles were wonderful, the topping tasted of pungent, ground earth, maybe not bad, but not my taste.

For dessert, we ordered the churros with Oaxacan chocolate.  This was off.  The churros were flavorless and not sweet enough although the texture was right.  The chocolate was bad.  The flavor was mingled with an unrecognizable savory, spice that we didn't care for at all.  

Had a fabulous 1.5 oz. pour of tequila.  Their tequila menu is extensive and organized by Highland and Lowland brands.  Also their take on the classic margarita is really fun with a salty foam topping that is delicious for those who enjoy a salted margarita.  

The prices are ridiculous which is why I am not giving the place 5 stars. But it's the new Vegas and long gone are the crappy $1.99 buffets about which I am certainly not complaining.  However, it seems we've moved to the opposite end of the spectrum, serving higher quality food while gouging people with prices 4 times the actual cost of the ingredients.  I hope in my lifetime, we see a happy balance between the two.

But if you're willing to blithely open your pocketbook, you're in for a great meal!

I needed to grab a quick snack while I was waiting to check in at the Cosmo, so I stopped by here.  I was tempted to grab dim sum, but seeing how overpriced it is tuned me out.  Instead, I grabbed the only sandwich on the menu.  However, it ended up being a small bun compared to the price-to-quantity ratio I had expected.  Though since this is Vegas, I probably should have lowered my standards even lower.

I admire the creativity, but this is really a tourist trap, if that hasn't been said enough already.

This is hands-down my favorite restaurant in Las Vegas. The service is friendly and the food is amazing. 

I grew up  eating home-cooked authentic Mexican food  and this place somehow not only matches but surpasses that experience !  If you are looking for good Mexican food this is the place ! My fave items so far: guac w/tortillas, tamale, ceviche, lotus chips, and tacos( my favorite tacos are the Carnitas and the napoles)

Some things are meant to be shared like the guac, ceviche, etc.  Others like tacos are more of an individual item.  The guac comes with tortillas which are delicious but I always get ceviche which comes with tortilla chips and I also get a side of lotus chips so I have an assortment of things to dip in my guac haha.  

 For chinese I reccomend the 20 vegetable fried rice.  I tend to stick to the Mexican side of the menu just because I love Mexican food haha but seriously you can't go wrong with anything on the menu here.  

For dessert, I highly recommend the mango sticky rice, their rendition is so unique and delicious.

Everything is prepared in open Chef stations so you know they are keeping things clean!  The atmosphere is fun and casual.  I try to eat here every chance I can.  I still have so many more things I want to try!

Do not eat here, nasty food.
$5.00 for a chicken potato taco.
$14.00 for 6 shu mai
$2.00 for hot sauce.... I wouldn't even come back for .99 cents

My second time here and it was just spot on.  Great fusion concept and dishes and portions are perfect for a date night.  Really helpful waitress taking care of us atthe bar and servers were outstanding.
What an adventurous menu!!  Great service from the moment we walked in to the moment we left.  Food was spectacular. Great concept Jose Andres

Not a fan went in for a quick $60 snack ! This place is not cheap portions are small. I wanted dim sum but they all had pork. I asked if there was one without pork and the guy told me beef. I ordered the vegetable dumplings that came out really bland and wet. They gave me soy sauce I asked if he had anything spicy to mix in brought out a sauce and charged me $2. I also had to ask three times for the sauce and I was sitting right at the bar stool infront of the guy. I would pass on this place definitely not worth it. The soup was also pretty bland.

BY FAR, my favorite restaurant in Vegas.  It's a must that I eat here every single time I'm in Las Vegas.  The Cochinita, Carnitas and RIP Barbacoa tacos are the best.  I was recently here for a trade show earlier in the week when a friend had to leave for an emergency and I left my favorite fidget toy, a torqbar at the restaurant.  Knowing it was a long shot, I called the restaurant and left a really weird and vague message knowing that even if they found it, no one would even know what it was.  Until only moments ago, after receiving a call from Catherine the night manager, did I know the integrity of the waitstaff and management as she is shipping my beloved torqbar to me tomorrow morning.  Thanks for reinforcing the fact that China Poblano is still my favorite restaurant and reminding me that there is still hope and love in this crazy world.

Jose Andres is a culinary mastermind so I was very excited when I saw that this was his place, but besides the sign exhibiting his name the excitement withdrew quickly.
I came here with a great friend from Hong Kong so the expectations were good quality Chinese food.

The food was very average with there signature "20 vegetable fried rice" for $19.88 being nothing more than your average fried rice that was actually over-seasoned with oyster sauce making it terribly salty and almost unpalatable. 

The pork buns were average but (4) for $13.88 was hefty price to pay for average dim sum pork buns.

The hot and sour soup had a strong after taste. 

The service was good and quick. The food came out very quickly which made us wonder if it was all prepared before hand.

One MUST TRY is the the drinks! I highly recommend Jose Andres' margarita . They had option to add pomegranate and that was just one amazing creation. 
Small quantity and $15 but a must try.

Over done flavors. Came here looking for a lite dinner after the super bowl. Easy to get in. The dishes are small which is okay and they are meant to be shared. I was looking forward to a nice salad to go with my small plates and they really didn't have one. The shu Mai were great. The shrimp was way over seasoned. The tequila flight was good but the sangria to chase it was way to spicy. Lettuce wraps were fine but not better than the ones from Costco. This place is not worth the money.

Chee*Nah Poh*Blah*Noh 

My lady friends and I stopped in to China Poblano this evening for a mixture of Chinese and Mexican shared plates. The restaurant was pretty full which is usually a great sign the food is amazing.

Ive been practicing a more pescatarian friendly diet and I was satisfied with the menu options.

What I Ordered:  
*20 Vegetable Fried Rice was flavorful. I enjoyed the variety of veggies Must TRY 
*Taco De Camaron yummy
*Table Side Guacamole was an excellent choice the bowl is much larger than the photos portray.
*Tuna Ceviche was my absolute favorite item. 

*Air Salted Margarita was delicious. I usually pass on the salted rim and was excited not to see it! The foam on top gave just the right amount of salt needed! Well crafted cocktail! 

I'll be back for some Dim Sum & thank you Miller our server for being knowledgeable!!!

I discovered this restaurant after viewing a recommendation by Anthony Bourdain, so while a friend was in town we decided to come check it out. It's located inside the Cosmopolitan Hotel which is one of my favorite places on the strip. Upon arrival we were greeted by a friendly hostess and offered our choice of the bar (which allows you to watch them work on tortillas from the open kitchen) or a table.  I felt for Vegas fine dining this place was pretty affordable.
Miller D was our server he was quick to greet us with a smile and I believe could tell we were unclear on if we should try a drink. He recommended the Sueno Cocktail which comes with a spicy salt rim. He was kind enough to do Half/Half in case we were a fan of the spicy kick it offered. Both my friend and I really enjoyed the drink.

The main thing I was dying to try was this taco that I read about called The Viva China Taco , but we also ordered a Happy Family Jiaozi  (delicious pot stickers with amazing flavoring)and Golden Pigs ( Fried Pork Buns) and some Beijing Glass noodles(cold noodle dish with avocado and jicama for an interesting twist). Overall I LOVED EVERYTHING except that Taco I wanted so badly to try. When it first arrived I took a bite of the Beef Tendon alone and it was delicious but when taking a bite of the taco all together with the oyster on top I felt like the ocean had thrown up in my mouth. It just wasn't a good combo for my pallet. Maybe I got a bad oyster I don't know but overall it was an experience I will not quickly forget.

Everyone at the restaurant was super friendly and our drinks were always full. The only reason I have to deduct a star is I somehow was overcharged $20 on my bill. Thankfully my friend encouraged me to keep my receipt and I am dealing with that situation but I definitely feel like this place is worth checking out! I left feeling satisfied and excited to go back to try some more cool fusions.

We decided to check this place out of curiosity. The cuisine is suppose to be Chinese and Mexican fusion but it's actually just the type of food that they serve there. 

To drink I ordered the Michelada with a Corona Light. It was pretty tasty and just what I needed after a serious night of heavy drinking ha 

For my main dish, I ordered the Chilaquiles: eggs, tortilla chips, cheese, cilantro, onions and topped with green chile sauce. It was okay. I've had better.

Atmosphere and decor really set up the mood for the meal. It's a very hip place. 

Service was great. They explain each food item with good detail. The Dan Dan noodles were not my favorite because the sauce is too sweet for me. 

Recommends: Nopal taco, Salt Air margarita, and Chicharron taco. The flavors of the tacos are very distinct, but blend very well. 

Pictured: Citrico Ceviche Tostada and Salt Air Margarita

What a great concept... Chinese and Mexican on one menu!  The twenty vegetable rice was spot on delicious!  The pork buns were extremely tasty.  I also had the chorico fundu... There was four of us and we all had different items. No complaints and we all left extremely pleased with the mix!

We had a great Christmas lunch here. 

Overall the food was good, but nothing to rave about. It takes some time to get used to having Chinese and Mexican at the same time. I recommend the rou jia mo street sandwich, shrimp mojo, and lamb potstickers. Papas frites (fries) were excellent as well, but I would order it with the toppings on the side. Just don't get the 20 vegetable fried rice...it was boring, the portion was tiny, and definitely not worth $16.88!

The main reason I'm giving it 5 stars is the desserts. They were amazing! we had mango sticky rice, happy buddha gello, and coconut tapioca balls. They were all delicious without being too sweet. 

I also loved the interior with funky mix of Mexican and Chinese decorations.

Quality: bland, average to below average tasting
Quantity: small 
Price: overpriced
Service: poor

I ordered 3 tacos: Lengua, Barbacoa, and Carnitas. The meats/fillings were dry and the combination of items (marinated onions, salsa, etc) were bland and didn't add any flavor to the overall bite. Definitely didn't leave me wanting more than I ordered.

Dan Dan Mian is probably the most decent dish we had but the portion was TINY. It should be an appetizer instead of an entre.

The Mongolian Beef Lettuce was more like a bed of romaine lettuce with some overcooked steak tips on top. Can totally skip this dish. 

Guacamole was decent and queso tasted like melted pizza cheese.

You would think they'd make up for average quality food with exceptional service - they didn't. While taking our order, the server was distracted and joked with another server who walked by. We had to pause so that she can finish her conversation..."I'm sorry, what did you order?" She also forgot my friend's taco order, which we reminded her twice about.

Overall, meh.

muy rico.  Stop by and get tuna ceviche m'kay esta con mandres.
 Tambien queso con chorizo

We had read so many wonderful reviews of this place, so we had high hopes.  The food is good, but the vibe is rather off-putting.  We shared the restaurant's version of hot and sour soup, which was spicy and creative and delicious.  I ate most of it.  Then we ordered the 20 vegetable fried rice and the bok choy.  The twenty vegetable fried rice, for all the youtube videos we'd seen about it, was a bit of a let-down, because there was a lot less veggies than the promo's had celebrated.  It was also a bit oily, which was a surprise, as I figured they'd had that part perfected.  The flavor was good.  The bok choy was also interesting, as it had a bit of citrus flavor, and it was thoughtfully prepared and not overcooked.  We also tried the guava agua fresca, which was refreshing and not too sweet.
Overall the food was better than good, and the service was great.  However, the place looks like a fast food joint from the outside, totally degrading its menu.  And once inside, it also appears cheaper than it should.  Also the pictures of the Mexican and Chinese people were sort of strange, especially the one of the Dali Lama, whose ethnicity is vague.

i've always had great experiences at this place. great food, great service. I dont like sitting on the little stool thing but i can easily get over that. 

we went there for my fiance's birthday, we has tacos, pozole, a couple orders of dim sum, noodles and a couple of deserts.

He ordered a Manhattan, which sat in the window a bit to long so he was a little disappointing but it wasn't a huge deal.

all in all we were very happy with the experience and will be returning soon!

My wife's birthday dinner start off well. The items we ordered was amazing. The service was great until we got another server, he was very rude. At the end of our meal, kept us if we wanted to order more food. We said, no we're stuffed. He cleared our table and gave us our check without asking us if we wanted dessert. As we were getting ready to leave, he picked up the bill counted the money and didn't say anything to us. We won't be coming back to this place.

Fantastic food... a bit pricey... but it's worth every penny!  Adore the decor!  The stuff - AMAZING!  The drinks - be careful - they're powerful!  My favorite is the Duck Tongue w/ Lychee Tacos and Fried Pork Bun with condensed milk dipping sauce = heaven!

Delicious, unique and well presented.
Interesting combination of flavors. Relaxing atmosphere.

Salt Air Margarita's
Hands down China Poblano makes the best Salt Air Margarita ever! We've gone to this restaurant just for the drinks, and am never disappointed with them. 

We also had the tasting meal previously before and that is well worth it. Everything on there is incredible.

I'd have to say we came here each time we visit Las Vegas just for the Salt Air Margarita

The China portion was much better than the Poblano portion of you catch my drift. The Mongolian Lettuce cups were good and the Dan Dan noodles and fried pork buns were nice fares too. 

The tacos were kind of boring and bland. Not a big fan. The salsa was missing some heat and could have used a little garlic for added depth of flavor. 

The service was ok. Typical for the Strip.

Scallops were delicious. If you get an Identity Membership card at the front desk (free btw) you get a complimentary margarita with the purchase of a margarita.

Overall, definitely an interesting menu combining both latin and asian cuisine to form a fusion of deliciousness.

Possibly one of the worst restaurant I've eaten at.
We were craving flavorful and savory food and saw china poblano and thought perfect because we love Chinese and mexican. Boy what a disappointment we had.
Everything was so bland and way overpriced for crappy food. We ordered several different tacos, ceaser salad, palm salad, posole and chips and salsa.
Tasteless and under par. The tacos at dell tacos or taco bell taste better.
The only thing that was ok were the chips, salsa was disappointing so then it made the chips not enjoyable.
Soooo delicious!  Tasted: pozole, chilaquiles, tacos, dimsum, fries.....all delicious!

What a delightful surprise!  I merely wanted a quick lunch after checking into the hotel, and someone said there was a "Chinese Mexican" place.  It tweaked my curiosity, so I tried it. The food was really interesting.  It's the best of Chinese and Mexican, but all prepared in a unique and stylish manner.  Expensive, with entree prices for small portions, but well worth it.
The foods here are so delicious and excellent but the portion is very little. Therefore, it would be pricey to fill your stomach if you're a huge eater! 100% recommended a must try!

this place sucked! food was soooo salty and soooo expensive for nothing.very very small portions of not good food.i mean i can make better tacos than this. its really a rip off.i mean reallyyyyyy. inhave tried his orher restaurants jaleo and felt thr exact same way.not sure what is up with the oversalting but when you are paying upwards of $10  for a single street taco and its crap,then you know you are basically getting ripped off. explains why the place was empty.

Service here was exceptional, the hostess showed us to our table quick, waitress came by quick and told us how the restaurant is (small portions), recommended what was good, and even the manager popped out of no where to offer some club soda to my friend when he got some sauce on his shirt, for the first time being here, that was great, sorry to all who had a bad waiter/waitress 

BUT....the food is just bad, terrible, overpriced Chinese/Mexican food that you hoped would at least taste good, but nah, I ordered wonton noodle soup, so honestly how do you screw this shit up, like I said this place is overpriced, I could have ordered the same bowl 5 times with tip at my local cafe...AND it would taste better lol.....place is bad for food, come here for.....the people? ha

So, I agree with several of the 3 stars here and I am leaning on probably a 3.5 for here but, I can't quite put a 4 down. This has been on my list to  eat visit for awhile because of its odd Asian/Mexican fusion which does not seem to make sense. The place itself is like an acid trip with videos on the walls, stadium seating at bar, and bike wheels on ceiling. 
The place is all small portion and sort of a tapas with large meal prices. 
My meal
Dan Dan Mian Noodles $12- really good with great flavor, a great soba noodles and sauce.
Chilaquiles $13- Which is basically tortilla chips, sour cream sauce, and a tomatillo type sauce. This is very close to a tradition version of this dish and it was good and rich.
20 vegetable fried rice $20- This was the best of them all, a great mix of veggies that I have eaten in such youthful form and great flavor.. However the size overall was probably 2 cups.

Desert- Mango rice $11- which was airy and very light with a cream rice flavor and cold mangos.

Drinks-Singapore Sling- Traditionally made and perfect! (where did these go America)

Salt Air Margariita- Crazy good with a salt flavored foam.

Overall a solid meal, however the bang for the buck is lacking. after tip this meal for 1 is over $90 and I can say I was not full in the end. So, the food is good but you are going to have to order 3 items per person to consider it a meal.

In a location as over the top as the Cosmo in Las Vegas, my wife and I were pleasantly surprised by lunch here. I wouldn't recommend as a destination for dinner, but if looking for a quick meal on the lighter side, it's one of very few options around, without being a stereotype of itself.

Good food, fantastic flavors, and enthusiastic service.

First off, we were robbed. Apart from the way overpriced food, I was surprised to see that someone forged a generous and undeserved 30% tip on my credit card bill, when I clearly left 15% on the receipt. Second, the food was mediocre at best. We started out with a couple of their signature cocktails which were fun and creative but not worth refilling our glasses with. The waiter was kind and willing, however his recommendations all fell flat on the palate. While the food was beautifully presented the taste was not impressive at all. We started with the Carnitas tacos which were bland and extremely oily. Next came the Lamb potstickers. The lamb filling was also not seasoned. Lastly we ordered the food network recommended 20 vegetable dish and added shrimp. Again the protein was bland and unseasoned. While the rice was somewhat tasty, it was not something to rave about. At the conclusion of our meal, we were somewhat shocked to see an $85 bill for the amount and quality of food that was ordered for 2 people. Despite the disappointing food, our waiter was nice and returned to our table multiple times to check on us. I believe this was mainly due to the fact that our order took a long time to arrive. Nevertheless I tipped 15% and clearly wrote the total of $100 on the receipt. Well, when I checked my bank, I noticed the 30% charge instead. I will be calling the restaurant today to dispute the issue. China Poblano is overrated and overpriced. Coupled with the billing issue, the overall experience was very disappointing. Needless to say we will not be giving it a second try.

Try the 20 vegetable rice! It's delicious. I really enjoyed the carnitas tacos and the Mongolian beef as well. I Wash it down with orange margaritas! The churro dessert with the hot chocolate glaze was a perfect ending to a very good dinner with friends. I would come back again.

It was getting late (at least for us still adjusting from Eastern time) for dinner on a Friday night.  We decided on China Poblano.  We're big fans of Jos Andrs, his restaurants, and his food.  However, despite multiple trips to Las Vegas, we hadn't yet dined at China Poblano.  Arriving around a little after 8PM, we had to wait a few minutes for seating at the bar to come available.

After a quick look over the menu, we decided to keep the decision-making process simple and have the Chef's Experience tasting menu ($45/person) with the Cocktail Experience ($32/person).  We received a nice selection of food from across the menu (Chips & Salsa, Tuna Ceviche Spoon, Siu Mai, Snow Pea Leaf Salad Carnitas Tacos, Shrimp Mojo, Twenty Vegetable Fried Rice, and Mango Sticky Rice).  Likewise, we received four, tasting sized (thankfully), cocktails from the cocktail menu (Salt Air Margarita, Ma, Jade Garden, and Mezcal Negroni) representing both Mexican and Chinese elements.  We had also ordered the When Pigs Fly (steamed barbecue pork buns), a supplemental item to the menu, which we didn't receive.  However, our gracious server, brought us a Churro in Oaxacan Hot Chocolate, to make up for the service oversight.  It was completely unnecessary, but much appreciated and a positive reflection of the restaurant's focus on customer satisfaction.  Going the tasting menu route worked well for us to sample as much of the menu as possible without leaving the restaurant uncomfortable full and/or inebriated.

Did China Poblano break any new ground or do anything better than traditional Chinese or Mexican restaurants?  Not so much.  I've certainly had better Chinese and Mexican food elsewhere and in most cases at a much lower price.  However, that's misses the point of China Poblano and why we went there for dinner.  It was a thoroughly enjoyable dining experience that honored both Chinese and Mexican cuisine with thoughtfully conceived and well executed food.  The same goes with the outstanding cocktails.  However, it was the service was the one facet of our experience that truly impressed and set China Poblano apart from most restaurants.

We were looking for a place to eat at the Cosmopolitan and stumbled upon this restaurant with an interesting concept.  We were seated quickly and had our own table (some of the tables are common).  If you are a vegetarian, there is not much for you on the menu as mostly everything (especially the Chinese side) has pork.  What you will get is very little for your money.  The Siu Mai is tiny, the soups are legit but small and the mexican coke is $6.  The biggest problem is that the food comes to you at different times so one of our friends got her tacos after we were 3/4th of the way through our meal.  I understand that they are working with different kitchens but come on....

Just went to China Poblano for Noodle wonton soup. The broth looks and tastes like beef broth. The noodle is not crisp and chewy. Not enough vegetable like wonton soup supposed to be. The wonton is fair. But it is overpriced  for half the portion most chinese restaurnat offer. Definitely need a change. If you are looking for authentic Chinese Noodle or Dim Sum, this is "not" the right place. Stay away from Fusion type restaurant. If you want good Ehenic foods, do not try fusion restaurant. I can't comment the Mexican restaurnat side. But I will not attempt based on the taste of Chinese food.

We were visiting from Out Of Town over Christmas and saw this place on one of the Hotel Channels in our room. I am a huge foodie, as is my partner and this place caught our eye as being a GREAT IDEA. 

My boyfriend LOVES Dim Sum and all things Chinese Food while I am a BBIIGGGG fan of Latin Food, especially Ceviche. 

While wandering the mall Christmas day we stumbled onto this spot by pure chance and decided to jump all over it. We were seated right away and initially noticed and beautiful decor. Whomever designed the inside of this place really had a solid idea in mind, the colours are bright and the themes meshes well with the Asian/ Mexican fusion. 

We ordered the drink we had seen on the ad, which was there Salt Air Margarita. It was really yummy. The Salt Foam really does coat the tongue and give you a very different experience as far as margarita drinking goes.  

For our food we ordered the Dim Sum Pot Stickers and the Ceviche plus a Taco. 

Dim Sum - Fair. Needed more flavor, stuffed with enough meat, but was lacking a solid taste.

Ceviche - Bad. We had the Snapper ceviche. It was so very bland, almost no flavor. I had to ask for Lime wedges to add onto the dish to give it some flavor. There was ZERO spice, and I am fairly sensitive to spicy foods. I'd HIGHLY recommend they add some sort of cirtus to their Cevich. 

Taco -  Decent. Meat had solid taste and was really tender, the tortilla was grand. 

Over all, it's a really great idea to fuse these two cuisines, I just think the technique missed the mark a little. They seem to carter to a specific type of person who doesn't seem to explore a lot of foods and it would be great to see them branch out and add more true flavors.

Come for the drinks. Not for the food.

Though Mexican-Chinese fusion food is not new (the same idea was done in the northern Mexican city of Monterrey, with its upscale "Chino Latino" restaurant), this restaurant can hold its own. The decor is modern, kitsch, and very inviting. Seating is limited at night, so make sure to make a reservation. The food here is actually not "fusion", per se, as asian-inspired and Mexican dishes are served on their own, and not "mixed". So, you can order pork dumplings and carnitas tacos separately. I believe this idea is lazy, but I would rather have well executed authentic food, rather than a failed attempt at some fusion. The Cochinita Pibil tacos are delicious, perfectly seasoned and very authentic. They taste very similar to what to would eat at the Yucatan peninsula. Of course, here they are way overpriced and served on a special taco gadget that keeps tacos standing up (to prevent spillage, I would assume). The Barbacoa tacos are also very authentic tasting, as well as the Pork Belly tacos. We also tried the 20-vegetable Fried Rice, as we'd previously seen someone on the Food Network claim it was the "best thing they ever ate" in Las Vegas. I would not go as far as saying it was the best thing here, but it is delicious. The "Mexican mimosas" are also very refreshing, though there is no such thing as a "Mexican mimosa"... The Margaritas, on the other hand, are modern and very tasty, as the salt element is done as a foam instead of only as a rim on the glass. Inventive and great. Do not order the Cajeta Flan, as it has NOTHING to do with a Mexican flan. I understand the chef was trying to add his own spin to this traditional dish, but I believe he should stick to what he knows best. It was nice, but it should not be named "flan", as it was more of a "crema catalana" (a typical dessert of the Catalunya region of Spain). The tortillas are hand-made, and you can reall taste the difference! I have to go back to try the Asian food. Overall, portions are tiny, so be prepared to order 4-5 per person. It is not cheap for the same reason. But, I will definitely come back.

We initially wanted to go to the buffet "Wicked Spoon" but was told that the place will be closing in an hour so we decided to check out a place near by instead and found "China Poblano".  I personally wonder how long this restaurant will last.  I did like the ambiance the place.  Our service was good and timely but the food is not worth the price.   Okay, so first off the server indicated to us that there were no scallops, no lobster and no crab so we had to change up our initial choices.  We ended up with the Mojo Shrimp, Steak Mole plate (I forget the name), sui mai quail eggs and sui mai scallop. So, the Mojo Shrimp was slightly undercooked and it tasted like it was doused in soy sauce reminding me of like Filipino adobo sauce (not in a good way).  The sauce was super salty.  We couldn't even finish the green beans in the sauce.  The Steak Mole plate according to my eating partner was cooked very good but it tasted like steak that I get in my local taco places around my apartment.  ( I live in the mission in SF so I'm surrounded by very satisfying Mexican food).  The mole sauce was pretty bland. The mushrooms and onions were super salty.  The sui mai was okay.  We were told that they could do scallop sui mai but we suspected that there were no scallops in it.  The quail egg sui mai was probably my favorite.  But again I live near a Chinese restaurant that does sui mai so I wasn't blown away. However, the quail egg was something I've never tried before and I wished that the whole experience was like that.  Eating unique dishes that elevated dishes that were traditionally Mexican or Chinese.  What we got was dishes that weren't unique enough for the price point.  The dishes are overpriced and small!  My friend ended up buying a hamburger and strawberry milkshake at Johnny Rockets afterwards.   I wouldn't recommend this restaurant to anyone except to deer who like salt lick.

Yuk. I wouldn't have chosen to eat here on a regular day, but considering this was the only restaurant in the cosmo that didn't have a $150 prixe fixe menu on NYE (who wants to stuff their face with $150 worth of food before dancing their ass off on NYE???) I had no choice. I made a reservation on opentable. A few days later they called me to take a credit card down since we had a party of more than 8, fine. A few days after that I randomly noticed that they dropped my reservation to 5:30?! If I had not noticed that we would've lost our space... wtf. Thankfully after I called, they were able to change it. 

They also had a set menu which was all shell fish and pork and had NO substitute options. Two of my guests couldn't even eat half the food. One of my friends who is allergic to shrimp, accidentally ate some and they didn't have benedryl on hand... that should be standard for a restaurant. I asked for them to comp her meal and they kindly agreed to do it, but after we paid I noticed that they charged for the makeshift substitutes they served... wow thanks for nothing! 

Last but definitely least, was the food. What a gross compilation of food. The worst was the vomit pepper... literally looked like a green pepper with baby vomit on it and it didn't taste much different. 

Nope nope nope...

"We have three kitchens, and everything comes out when it's ready, so it may not be together, ok?" Well...not really. I ordered 2 tacos and hubby got Chinese Spare Ribs, I got one taco while he just sat there for a long time, his food came, and my second taco came out after he was through and we were twiddling our thumbs. I somewhat appreciate their honesty, but...no...bring it out at the same time. The guacamole was wonderful -- order it with crunchy chips like I saw (after we just ordered it) other tables had. The guac alone was worth it. My Pescado Estilo Baja taco not as good as the Carnitas, a surprise. A good idea, though, if some of your party wants Chinese and some want Mexican...

While staying  at the cosmopolitan I was lucky enough to have easy access to China poblano. My first meal consisted of " when pigs fly" and " golden pigs". The golden pigs were awesome. They had sweet tender pork filling with a hint of 5 spice ( I think) and came with house made sweetened condensed milk which was delish. There at 4 to a serving..but they are filling. The when pigs fly were the same filling..only these were steamed..not fried golden..and came with no dipping sauce. I was pleased..but would have liked a dip!  Second trip I ordered the 18 monk noodle.. And took it to go since I was solo..I guess it was because I took it up to my room..but the noodles were a bit dry..and the portion was a tad bit small. One stand out that I had both times were the pork carnitas tacos. The filling was super juicy and came with two chicharones inside. I could have eaten 10.

I so wanted to love it, because Jose Andres is totally awesome!  But it wasn't good.  Will not comment on a price, fine it is Vegas, but was kind of expecting something great.  We eat dim sums every week, so not a new flavor profile to me.  Siu Mai was very salty, I couldn't really taste other flavors, shrimp Har Gow was fine, but hot and sour soup was truly awful - didn't resemble anything Chinese in flavor and a thick layer of of oil on top was just yucky.

Who would've thought we'd find the best pozole ever at a little spot like this inside the Cosmopolitan in Vegas? And like our server Kevin joked with us when we ordered, "It's better than your grandmother's." My wife and I stopped in last weekend after having been to Jaleo a couple days earlier, which is the other restaurant by Chef Jose Andres inside the Cosmopolitan and we loved it so we thought, "how can we go wrong?" The pozole and the chilaquiles were both fantastic but the pozole stood out huge for us. Kevin informed us that Chef Andres served this same pozole at Salma Hayek's wedding, interesting little tidbit of info there. In any case, if you're a pozole fan do yourself a favor and stop in.This stuff will part your hair, I'll tell ya. It's insane. We actually left wishing we had tried something else here too but we just couldn't force ourselves. There's always next time. 

Speaking of Kevin, (the guy with the groovy mustache another Yelper mentioned) he helped make our experience here all the more better. Right from the start, with his super friendly vibe, he went above and beyond to make my wife and I feel like old friends stopping by his own home for lunch. He was all over it and never left us needing for anything. He loves taking care of people and it definitely shows. Stop in and ask for Kevin. He provides a five star experience on all fronts. 

Although the concept of Chinese and Mexican food being served side by side may seem a little odd, our blissful food coma and the great service from the entire team at China Poblano made it well worth the stop. We already plan on dropping in on our next trip.

My first time at the Cosmopolitan hotel and was hungry so went upstairs to find this restaurant! 
Got seated right away and asked the server what their most popular dishes were from the China menu section and he told us couple options.
Bf ordered dan dan mian (kind of dry but was still delish) and I ordered the twenty-vegetable fried rice which was very delish!
I did not feel guilty after eating my dish because it was full of different types of vegetables!

we only decided to come here because we wanted a light snack before hitting up Bacchanal buffet, boy was this place a mistake.

first- this place is extremely over priced for quality and quantity of food you get. 

     quality wise- the food is extremely salty. 
     quantity- super small portion 

lotus chips- only delicious part of entire meal, crisp & properly seasoned.

the rou jia mo sandwich was horrible- buns fall apart and are oily-- the "braised" pork was cut in cubes and was sooooooooo SALTY.  it seemed to be braised in nothing but soy sauce - lack of any asian/mexican seasoning it seems.  such a disappointment. 

tuna ceviche- lack of seasoning in initial bite and then salt creeps up on you slaps you in the face. 50%  nuts/filler fufu crap, no substantial amount tuna. absolutely disgusting. not what i imagined and chinese mexican ceviche to taste like, no explosion of flavor, lacked acidz 


second- service by server "Franco" was absolutely horrible. he was rushing the entire time as if there were more people to serve (place was practically empty). he grabbed our plates before being finished

    manager was polite-- she ended up comping our items due to bad service/food. she's the only reason i'm giving 1 star. 

definitely beware of this place.

Super yummy!

I ate a lot of different stuff here...Tacos, pork rolls, noodles, rice
...if anything eat the "20 Vegetable Fried Rice"! I heard from several people...best fried rice EVER! Each bite was different and super awesome!

Very causal, relaxed place, great cocktails.

Everything I ate was great! Service was great! Seating was easy!

Go eat a taco, fried rice and pork buns, you won't be sad!
My friends hyped this place up so much, it's decent Chinese food but by far not the best I've had. At least the prices are very decent for being in the cosmopolitan.

First off , the food sounds better than it actually is, then the portion are way smaller than average and finally the price is really really over priced. 

The Food isn't really fusion mix, the food quality is so-so. 

The Portion are super small, salad, 4 bites. Pork bun thingy, 2 bites, 

The Price is very expensive for 4 bites of salad. 

I understand the whole concept of quality vs. quantity, but this doesn't apply, quality isn't really there, and quality isn't really there. After eating here, we had to go else where to find a quick bite, because we were still hungry after, and this was a $80 bill lunch.

Seriously, do not go unless you have money to blow! and time to go eat after!
Always a staple for anytime.   Expensive but tapas style perfect for groups.   The Asian side amazing.  Mexican side also.  Silencio tacos were bomb.

Was so disappointed after my visit here, great concept but ultimately the food looked nice but tasted very bland and was not worth the price. The golden pigs were recommended by the waiter but the pork filling was literally flavorless; just a sort of gelled consistency surrounded by a fried dough that when dipped in the sweetened condensed milk ultimately tasted like a donut. The lengua taco was ok, but not really a lot of flavor. My husband and I envisioned going there and enjoying a variety of small flavorful dishes but given the price and our experience with the taco and golden pigs, we stopped and paid there. We only ate 2 of the 4 golden pigs and hoped our waiter would ask if we liked it, but he only asked "can I get you anything else?", so we just asked for the check. I'm so glad we started with just two items, and for the record we ordered them at the same time and hadn't been there for long, so I don't think we had annoyed the waiter. It's just sad that it wasn't delicious and I wouldn't recommend that anyone spend their money there.
Best margaritas in Vegas!!! the guac was really good! the bartender made a special margarita for me with Serrano peppers and tamarind! it was amazing! he should name it The Lola Margarita :):):):):)

Some girlfriends and I spent the weekend of 4/20 in Vegas...which was kinda amazing. But do you know what lacked amazingness? This place!

My friend REALLY wanted to go here because she has some kind of "foodie crush" on the dude that opened the place. Or the head chef. Or someone important like that. We all assumed it was going to be a Mexican/Chinese fusion- but the two sides of the menu (and the dishes) are completely separate.

While the atmosphere, and the idea, are both super fun, the place lacks execution. I was not a fan of my soup, and while my lemon shrimp were bomb in flavor, they didn't sit well later!

With so many culinary gems in the city of sin, I suggest you indulge elsewhere!

Really really really wanted to love this. I came in with high expectations, especially because I am a fan of Jose Andres's style. He is creative and has a vision that is unique in the restaurant world. The kitchen needs to see his same vision. 

The layout of the restaurant is stunning. Two bars upon entry (left and right) and your in direct sight of the dimsum preparation and steamers. There are creative cocktails to choose from, & the bar has an embedded part of the design to hold a spoon...then dissapointment began. 
Without being longwinded,  Salty! Over priced! Really dissapointing! 

This was the order: Viva China* soft beef tendon/ Kumamoto oysters/scallions/ Sichuan peppercorn sauce -- it was one tiny taco, this was my only tasty thing but the price was a serious turn off for the size. Pescado Frito fried fish/ ancho chile pickled onions taco-- again just OKAY, doesn't justify the cost. Beef 6pc beef/lime/ daikon/ watermelon radish --DIMSUM, I've had better. AND the clincher Shrimp Mojo 8 pc shrimp/sweet black garlic/roasted poblano peppers--Salty

I don't know if the kitchen was off that day but I rarely send things back and the salt content was so powerful we just had to say something. We got the dish made fresh again and sad to say, nothing changed.

Our bill was approximately $110 and it left us starved for a second meal that wasn't going to leave us with high blood pressure. I understand that good quality will justify higher priced cuisine but these portion sizes were abnoxious. They should even slightly up the price and give us two tacos instead! Eating with your eyes is the first step to the dining experience and that left us hungry. 

I will definitely continue to visit Jose Andres's other projects but will stay away from China Poblano in the Cosmo when Blue Ribbon sushi satisfies me a lot more in the same price range!!

The verdict in this place...identity crisis? This place is not fusion. It truly does serve both Chinese and Mexican cuisines. The server deems it authentic, but with a culinary twist. So, if the Chinese dishes may be a favorite for you at your Chinese restaurant, then it may not be what you expect at China Poblano. Don't get me wrong, the food was good. But overpriced and super salty. The Ocean's Nest pan fried seafood noodle was almost $40. Way too salty. The Dian Dian Mian was good but salty again.

OK, for a bowl of veggie rice, an order of chilled noodles,(1) taco, and an order of stuffed dumplings,a non refillable can of diet coke and , small cup of cantaloupe juice .I paid a whopping 91.50. The portions sizes were very upsetting,(infact I cried a little before leaving) the dumplings tasted similar to play-doh (don't judge me) play-doh being the Victor in the taste comparison. The taco was the size of a Japanese hornet small when compared to an average tacos. I wouldn't recommend this place to my worst enemy.I will never be returning.maybe just to yell through the window "you suck!"I would rather eat Vegas desert  dirt.

No. No. No. Asian food is blan or just a bunch of soy sauce.. They charge for hot sauce.. they charge for salsa refill and chips.. not worth it. Epic fail. Found hair in our complimentary wontons that we got because our food was late. Fyi. Seating in the outside by the entrance is uncomfortable

Loved it. Chinese and Mexican tapas. I would give it 5 stars but the prices for drinks    are a bit much. $18.00 for a gin and tonic and $15.00 for a margarita. Yes, the drinks were good but not that good. Service was great,nice, attentive and cleared empty plates quickly. Onto the food. We had the following, sorry don't remember specific names of things. 
1. Taco - yummy and authentic
2. Spring rolls- a bit greasy but delicious
3. Odon noodles- very spicy
4. Dumplings- very good
5. 20 vegetable fried rice- omg it's a must try and add beef or chicken for more deliciousness. 

So these 5 items are plenty for two people. This and the 2 drinks= $ 117.00 before tip

Will I back.....you betcha!

They have an interesting concept but this is another fusion restaurant that has an identity crisis. I went here with a large party and everyone left unsatisfied. We tried just about everything on the menu. I don't think the food was disgusting. But we were not impressed and it ABSOLUTELY was not worth the price. We were the only ones in the restaurant but service was slow and not very friendly.
This place is amazing.  The veggie bowl is beautiful and tastes so good even with no meat!  The pork sandwich and carnitas taco were legendary!

When I saw China Poblano on Food TV's "Best Thing I Ever Ate: Las Vegas," I knew we had to go when we were out there. It's a restaurant designed for us, really - Mexican and Chinese. Not fusion, but three separate kitchens taking care of both of our food needs at once, without one of us sitting and watching the other eat. Being that it was Jos Andrs, we had high hopes, and they were met easily.

His plate: Papas Fritas with Mexican cream and queso fresco; Carnitas taco (braised baby pig, pork rinds, spicy salsa verde cruda); Pescado Frito taco (fried fish, salsa Mexicana)

Her plate: "When Pigs Fly" - delicate steamed buns with Chinese barbecue pork; "Ocean Nest" - scallops/shrimp/king crab/lobster/pan-fried egg noodles/ seasonal vegetables; "Salt Air Margarita"

To share: Chips and Salsa - fresh tortilla chips, house-made chipotle salsa

The chips and salsa were good, though nothing out of this world. The pork buns were the only actually disappointing part of the meal - the dough is a little gummy and maybe overworked - though the filling was flavorful and moist, and happily not over-salty. We ended up taking these home and they were better as cold leftovers in the middle of the night.

My pan-fried egg noodles were nice and crisp, with a deliciously oceany broth. There was no king crab, which I'd been looking forward to, but the shrimp had their heads on and were fantastically fresh. The bok choy was the perfect choice for the 'seasonal vegetable' and I'd definitely get this dish again. The ocean flavor was just so good.

The fries were described as good, but not memorable. D's tacos were both fantastic, full of flavor and great textural contrasts. The carnitas were not slimy, as they are at some restaurants, and were nicely accented by the pork rinds on top. Since we've been home, the tacos have been mentioned a few times. We'd love it if Jos added a China Poblano in DC, but we'll also definitely visit it again when we're in Vegas next year.

In Vegas from L.A. Reviewing food.(service was great ).
The tacos are really well executed:you can taste the ingredients and the housemade tortillas are supple and melt in your mouth with the filling.Not gonna list them all, but they were all excellent to our taste.
 The Huitlacoche "shaved pasta", needed salt .The pasta were nice though, with a great texture but the spiciness overwhelmed the dish.We still managed to finish the bowl.
Shrimp Mojo was tasty,the flavors well balanced, although we thought they would have been nice served with an accompaniment .
The must have to finish your meal: The sticky rice foam and mango.Their take on the classic Thai dessert (sticky rice and mango).When our waiter described it to us I was drewling! And It was beyond belief! I would go back just for that.

the food is good, the prices, not so good. 

i had the barbacoa taco, golden pigs, and quail egg siu mai. 

the barbacoa taco had a spicy, tender beef in it. it was $5 for a small taco, but what do you expect in vegas?

the golden pigs ($14.88/4 buns) are "fried delicate steamed buns/Chinese barbeque pork/ condensed milk." basically, fried bbq pork buns -- they're perfectly fried and not greasy at all. the meat inside was piping hot, flavorful, and the perfect mix of sweet and savory. the condensed milk is kind of thinner than what i'm used to, but it is the perfect complement to the sweet and savory bun. i'm undecided if this should be a dessert item or not, but it's that good. we had 2 orders of this. 

the quail egg siu mai has shrimp/pork/peanuts/ poached quail eggs --- basically, siu mai you'd get at dim sum, but with a perfectly poached quail egg on top. also costs 5x more than your average order of siu mai (6 pcs for $16.88!). 

also, get the monk chili sauce. it's a spicy chili oil to dip anything and everything in and it adds good flavor and heat. 

other favorites among my group include the duck tongue/lychee tacos (sweet and savory combo), and the viva china taco (beef tongue, kumamoto oyster, scallions). my bf also loved the lamb pot stickers, and he usually hates pot stickers that "aren't made at home with TLC." haha pot sticker snob. 

the prices here are definitely steep, but the food is good. you can really tell that every ingredient is fresh and high quality. there are unique flavors and items here, and if you're willing to splurge a bit, take some friends (it's small plates/tapas sized portions) and dig in.

Chinese food and Mexican food in one - what more could you ask for?

I'm honestly pretty shocked about the lack of positive reviews for China Poblano.  It's Vegas - everything is expensive and probably not big enough (insert double entendre here).  Stop your whining and realize it's tapas-style.  If you have 10 hungry bachelorette party girls like we were, order two of each type, eat family style, order a strong drink, and shut your trap.

For Vegas shu mai, I thought it was pretty good.  We ordered two servings of the Lucky 8, which I recommend so you can get a taste of each type of shu mai they serve. All were tasty and topped with something interesting, like radish or goji berry. The har gau was ok; I have had better. The Don't Be Jealous hot and sour soup had a wonderful kick of spices. Drinks ordered included the Singapore Sling and the Lychee Sour, both of which were flavorful and interesting. I myself had vodka with fresh cantaloupe juice, which snuck up on you and hit you like an unruly child. Other dishes ordered at our table included a caesar salad (with way too much parmesan), When Pigs Fly, shrimp, and numerous tacos. As far as pork buns go, the When Pigs Fly was a little meh. I like the pork to be red and drier than this was.

The coup de grace of my palate was the Viva China taco. This is definitely the best non-traditional taco I've ever had. A taco with beef tendon and oyster - the crispiness of the tendon punctuated with the creamy oyster was mind-blowing. 

Lots of good tastes, a few mediocre tastes. But definitely deserving of a higher rating than the uno estrellas some other folks are giving. I'd go back.  Viva China Poblano!

We ended up here about twice in just as many days, because there was almost too much to try in one sitting.  They've got a couple open kitchen stations - one for some of the Mexican items and another with a huge steamer for the Chinese dumplings, plus an area for making noodles.  I have to say that at the rather odd hours we were in, we didn't see much more than a few egg rolls being wrapped, however.

They have a fairly large cocktail menu with some interesting, though confusing things, and notably have a couple Chinese beers by the bottle that I had not seen before.

We tried a couple tacos - Silencio, with duck tongue and lychee, was quite good, the duck tongue being very approachable.  Viva China, with tendon and oyster, was similarly unthreatening.  In general, though the flavors were good and the textures were decent, these tacos put so many different components together that they often got lost in each other.

Lamb Potstickers were good, and reasonably, but again not emphatically, lamby.

Huitlacoche Noodles were a little disappointing.  The noodles had a nice texture, but we had a hard time detecting much huitlacoche flavor.

The braised pork sandwich ( Rou Jia Mo Street Sandwich ) was awesome, but about two bites.

We came back specifically to try the Twenty-Vegetable Fried Rice.  Expensive at $17.88, it is possible that they did in fact include 20 vegetables, cut into very small cubes, somewhere within the rather small portion.  But in the end it was just that:  fried rice.

We were hoping to see a lot more fusion on the menu, but most dishes were segregated onto one side or the other.  We enjoyed both our experiences - the servers were accommodating, though very casual, and there was a lot to look at in the space, from the cooking going on to the walls of offbeat art.  Overall, and keeping in mind that this is in a fancy hotel casino in the middle of the desert, the food is remarkably good for the location.

Went here again last night with my sister. You gotta love this place! so many unique dishes on the menu, and their service is the best. We met an awesome guy named Miller who was our waiter. We talked a little bit about where we were both from, he gave us plenty of time to look at the menu and was super nice. And he made sure we got everything we needed. A couple times the food runner brought the wrong stuff and Miller was quick to get it switched. I totally recommend this place to anyone who likes mexican or asian cuisine. Its an "experience" to be enjoyed.

The concept of this place is crazy.  It's also bordering on criminal to charge $4 and up per taco regardless of how good the ingredients are.  The Chinese food well let's just put that aside. 

The tacos are pretty good but seriously these prices are absurd even by Vegas standards especially the portion size.  I can get tacos in many places in LA or OC for $1.25 that are many times superior (2 Guys, Taco Leo).  Taking aside these huge issues the tacos are good but not as authentic - I don't care how many abuelas you have making toritllas in the front of the house.

The Chinese food is like a more authentic version of PF Chang but dim sum style.  Again the food is tasty but about 3x in price of much better stuff I can get in dozens of places in SGV. 

The Bazaar is great this place is just weird and expensive.

Very fun and hip atmosphere.  Seating isnt the most comfy but I love the ambiance and the decor.  It's a little asian and a little bit mexican.  The food is excellent.  There are really fun choices.  The mango sticky rice was soooo different than the traditional kind that you get at normal Thai places.  You have to try it to understand what I experienced.  I loved the barbacoa tacos and wished they were bigger but at least I had room to eat other things.  The carnitas taco was also good.  The langosta was so rich and tasty.  The mole fries was not my favorite since it was too heavy on sauce and made the fries soggy.  The pozole was also really good but too large - share it with someone.

This once was one of my favorite spots in Vegas. But the past couple of times the service and food have been off. I am allergic to oysters and the first few times I went staff were very accommodating. The past times, they have seemed annoyed and just told me to stay away from most of the most popular dishes. The drinks were still good, and the potential is there, but I won't be wasting a meal coming back here.

So nice I ate there twice. In town for a work conference and was intrigued by the fusion menu. The service was just incredibly nice and perfectly timed. Everyone here is genuinely awesome. What I ate:

Wontons: I've been looking everywhere for this thin wrapper for my homemade wontons, but I'll happily pay for the ones at China Poblano. Perfectly crispy and crunchy, with a solidly delicious filling and the dark soy sauce is yummy. Ask for some chili sauce to up the flavor explosion. These really remind me of the wontons that I've had in Trinidad so I'm obsessed. 

Dan-Dan Mian: I liked this but the sauce was a bit salty for my taste and even though I mixed it, didn't feel like I was getting the right amount of pork/peanuts. That's probably user error. The hand cut noodles were perfect though. 

Siu Mai: the traditional siu mai was simply delicious pockets of heaven. This is a must try!

Mongolian Beef Lettuce: this was also delicious and a large portion. Loved the shishito peppers and the sauce was perfect. The beef filet tips were also perfectly marinated.

The menu is very large.  Almost TOO big... I recommend that you do what we did and turn over some decision making to the waiter. 

We had the garlic shrimp...which should be labeled with a DONT EAT ON A FIRAT DATE logo or come with a bottle of listerine...JEEZ!  It was excellent.  

We also had the mini burgers, liked them so much that we ordered 2 more!  

We also had the tomato bread or some thing?  Listen, it's Vegas, there were cocktails involved, I don't remember what it was called!  Order it; ridiculous.

We went crazy and then had the fig jam cheese for dessert.  It's $30, and totally worth it!!!

I LOVED the tacos! 

My friend and I each ordered two because we wanted a snack before dinner. But they were so good that I ordered one more and she ordered two more. I didn't know it was a restaurant by Andres until I overheard a server telling another table. I wasn't surprised each taco was $5 because I'm used to overpaying in Vegas but it was well worth it! Each taco was so flavorful!

Conchinita - bbq pork with magenta-colored marinated onions

Barbacoa del Res- bbq beef with chile and pickled cactus

Pancita al Pastor - pork belly with pineapple

This is a great place to get quality food for cheap, but the menu is very uneven. 
We had dinner at this place, and got a few dishes to share. Dishes are pretty small, so I think sharing is the best option at this place. 
Based on reviews we read we didn't get any salad, and I guess the reviews are right- the table next to us sent back two salads and complained they were both bad. It's a shame because there aren't many vegetable dishes on the menu as it is. 
Other than that- everything we got was really good. We enjoyed all the dishes we got. 
I should mention the waiter forgot to write down one of the dishes we ordered and asked if we want to see the dessert menu before we got it. This made us wait too long for that dish and we got no compensation for that, and not even an apology.

It was really strange tapas style atmosphere with things coming at all different times, but I'll be back.   The one thing that I didn't get is them telling customers that the kitchen was closing in 10 minutes as 2000 of us exited the Chelsea from a concert.  Coordinate people!!!! A lot of people walked away because of that, and for the few of us that ate, the waitress was running around frantically.

So I went back to China Poblano to relive my 30th birthday last year (which was awesomely spent working the week in Vegas and then spending the night at the Cosmopolitan and eating here).  Really I came back because the food was decent, I dug the experience and the wait staff I had last time was memorable.  I felt bad for my dad because he is not as of an adventurous of an eater as I am, but he did find a noodle dish he enjoyed.  All in all, second time was a charm as well!

I'm shocked by how low the average rating here is, this is one of my favorite places to eat when I'm in Vegas.  We discovered it totally by accident while roaming through the newest building on the strip, looking for a fun meal. The initial outside appearance of the restaurant made me think it was a food court, but once I saw the name Jose Andres, I knew we were in for something special,  and I wasn't disappointed.

That was over a year ago, since then we have been back several times.  The highest compliment that I can pay to the food is that every time I leave China Poblano, I leave energized, excited, and euphoric.

When China Poblano gets it right, they get it very right, witness the Viva China, beef tendon and Kumamoto Oyster taco.  It's simple, yet enthralling, an amazing contrast of texture, temperature, and flavor.  Every time I have one, it's just as good as the first.

There are a number of other shining stars, like the Barbacoa and Silenco (spicy duck tongue and lychee!) tacos, and several of the desserts (I still dream about the Tres Lychees, why did they have to take it away?!?!?!).  The noodles I've tried were quite good (especially the spicy Dan Dan Mian), but not quite up to the level of the zany tacos.

I have sampled a few things that I'd classify as merely "good" like the chocolate terra cotta warrior, and the fried wantons, and there is a large swath of the menu that I've yet to try.

Yes, it can be a bit pricey for the quantity of food/drink, but consider the location, and more importantly consider the creative, meticulously prepared food.  You get what you pay for.

However, those items that I love make China Poblano a destination entirely on their own, not to mention the fun atmosphere and excellent service.  On that note, our servers have always been not just friendly and accommodating, but very knowledgeable about the food as well, and I think that really makes a difference in the overall experience.

I'm always happy to be coming back to China Poblano.  It's a great place to start or end your Vegas trip, or perhaps even for a late night in the middle.  This last trip, we did all three!

Are you looking for authentic Chinese and/or Mexican food? Do you enjoy unique fusion combos? Is it important for you to get good value in terms of quality/quantity vs price? If you answered yes to any of these questions, do not bother eating at this place.

The decor and service are top notch, I will give them that. But a restaurant is about food first and foremost, and those things should be there to complement the experience, not make up for bad food. I had the Golden Pigs, the Lamb Pot Stickers, the Har Gau, and the Swallow a Cloud. The portions were ridiculously tiny: I could've fit all six pieces of Har Gau in one bite. The noodle soup was really bland. 

Everything about the restaurant looks unique, fancy, and pricy: all usually good indications. But not here. Here, "unique, fancy, and pricy" are the indications of pretentiousness. Don't be drawn in.
A friend who lives in Vegas recommended this place and it did not disappoint.  One of the best tacos I have ever had and the braised pork sandwich, although small, was amazing.

The tacos are delicious! 

My favorite is the Carnitas - braised baby pig and spicy salsa verde w/ pork rinds!!! The Barbacoa de Res was pretty good too. 

The Langosta (lobster) taco's were OK. I don't think it was worth it for the price. 

The tacos are the size of Mexican street tacos so order a few to taste. 

The Beijing Glass noodles is a yummy cold noodle dish w/ veggies. I found it refreshing. The avocados on top were a good mix. 

I also had the Har Gau dumplings. The outside of the dumpling was good, dumplings must be freshly made, but I thought the inside could use a little more taste. 

Overall, this is a pretty good place for higher end China/Mex. It's tough to find a China Mex restaurant anyway.

My fianc and I finally stumbled in and we were definitely impressed. We were seated at the bar and were greeted by Jason the bartender. He was very warm and friendly and did a wonderful job of answering our questions about the menu and suggesting menu items. The combination of Chinese and Mexican food seemed a little odd at first, but it was exceptionally delicious. I had the black bean taco without cheese and vegetable fried rice. We ordered table side guacamole and it was perfect. The food was so full of flavor and was seasoned perfectly.  I ordered a salty air margarita because the look of the drink grabbed my curiosity. The service was fast, friendly and the overall ambience of the place was soothing. The restaurant has left me wanting to go back and experience more of the menu. As a Mexican American that grew up in L.A. around an abundance of authentic Mexican and Chinese eateries, this place was a wonderful surprise. Our expectations were definitely exceeded. We will be back again.

Review:  20 Veg Fried Rice / Red Braised Pork Street Sandwich

We specifically went to this restaurant to try the 20 Veg Fried Rice ($17.88) that was featured on Foodnetwork's "Best Thing I Ever Ate."  LOVED it!  I wish I could duplicate the sauce.  Big bowl, definitely feeds 2 as a main dish, 3-4 as a side.  My husband had the Red Braised Pork Street Sandwich ($8) and he said it was very good.  Pricey though for a very small sandwich.  Still, the quality is outstanding and I'd rather eat less and pay more for great food.  Bench style seating on community tables is hard on the back (no back rests); very sleek modern style - interesting ever changing graphics projected on the walls.  I'd go back for the Veg Fried Rice and would like to try their other food.  Great quality!

My mother was staying at the Cosmopolitan for a conference, so I spent the day with her after picking her up at the airport. We hit up China Poblano because it was in the hotel and wasn't fine dining  and looked more interesting than the burger place next door. I was honestly disappointed. 

The food was average - some of it was very good, like the dumplings, and then some of it I've had better at super cheap joins in Chinatown. I was feeling boring and ordered tacos, and they were really bland. It wasn't BAD, it just wasn't worth the price. The cocktails were good and the service was great, however, so kudos to the staff. 

The worst part for me, however, was the seating. I would have enjoyed this experience infinitely more if I hadn't been expected to sit on a bench or a stool. To my eye (we sat on the "Mexican side" of the restaurant) there was only ONE area where any of the seating had a back - along a wall, which faced ... more backless, wooden stools. It was so impossibly uncomfortable, I found it really difficult to be objective about what I was eating. Half the seating looked like high school lunch tables. It was really awkward. I promise, there are chairs in Mexico! No matter how okay some of the food was, even if somebody offered to comp my entire order there, I probably wouldn't go back, just so I wouldn't have to sit there again.

Should have gotten burgers next door.
Besides the nice decor, the food is lackluster at best. Small portions and over priced. I'd rather spend my money at chipotle.

I love how they roll the tortillas and buns in front of you while you are waiting. I enjoyed all my food. I ordered the spicy shrimp Mexican dish which was great. The pork buns were great as well. I definitely recommend the elote if you like a little spicy. For the desert, I was in love with the mango sticky rice. It was a mango sticky rice with a twist. It was real mango w mango sorbet, coconut cream, and crispy rice at the top.

This was a neat and unique upscale blend of a restaurant with an identity crisis. This crisis however led to a nice fusion of Mexican and Chinese cuisine. A quaint and cozy setting inside the cosmopolitan hotel and located on their second floor China Poblano has delicious food with my vegetable fried brown rice with chicken having an amazing combination of Mexican and Chinese flavor. The prices are very reasonable for Las Vegas. Neither the restaurant, the setting, or the food blew my mind, but I would eat here again. The service was good and the ambience was enjoyable.

The food was unique and full of flavor. My favorite were the Asian street tacos. The meat was very flavorful. I do not recommend this place if you are looking for good meals though, the portions are very small and a bit pricey. The place was so cool and very colorful!

I can understand why people gave 3.5 stars to this place. Not sure if it's the same reason though. For me, it's just too little food for expensive price. Nothing too special, taste is good, but very ordinary. ???????????????????fortunately the ABC waiter told me about it. So I'm appreciative.

The Cosmo is one of the most hip and happenin' spots on the strip.  China Poblano is a great place to eat and share interesting fusion dishes before continuing on with the night.  The service is snarky, prices are high for what you get, and the ambiance is pretty loud but hey, It's Vegas.  It's fast and easy and...well...HIP!

You need to go at least once I think. The food was executed beautifully, and the flavors were provocative. As the meal came to a close, I was nodding my head in approval, but then the bill arrived, and I realized I was still a bit hungry. I don't think the prices were insane; they just add up quickly. 

I love the atmosphere, as if you're walking into the LSD trip of a luchador on a dragon boat. The waitress was notable in her attention to our questions regarding dietary restrictions. If you have a dietary restriction, they take it seriously, which is always a good thing to know. However, our water glasses did remain empty for a quarter of the meal. Nothing worth complaining about too loudly, just an odd disconnect between the quality of service we initially received. 

As for the food, we started with some good ol' chips and salsa. Why? I am not sure, but I would resist. The salsa was a-ok, but didn't  thrill my buds. We each had a taco. I went for the pastor with thinly sliced pineapple, and the pork belly was good, but I thought the sauce could have gone in a different direction. It overpowered the lovely pineapple.

The two standout dishes were the chilaquiles, a must if you adore cheese, and the snow pea salad dressed with citrus. I confess it was my first time eating snow peas raw, and I find this a distinct upgrade on a lettuce salad. It is quite stemmy, but I don't care.

Will I return? For a sit down experience, probably not, but I may have to roll up to their to-go window just for the hey of it. I just like the idea of ordering a Jose taco to go from a window.

If I could give this place 0 stars, I would! Sorry excuse for tacos, and for that $22 fried rice. DEFINITELY not worth your money. Also, it seems like they pick up just about anyone to be a manager at that place because Megan was completely disrespectful and instead of helping us with our order, she chose to argue and insult our party. If you know what's good for you, just stay away and get tacos from tacos el gordo.

I wish I were more hungry when I came to China Poblano. My boyfriend and I on a whim decided to eat here while in Vegas and we were not disappointed. We tried a handful of things: ceviche, queso con chorizo, and tacos. If you're a cheese lover, please get the queso con chorizo. It was easily the best cheese appetizer I've ever had in my life! 

Atmosphere is really great and a fun, casual dining experience. The staff is spot on and paced perfectly. My only recommendation is that this isn't a quick in and out food experience. If you go, make sure you plan on staying to enjoy!
Chipotle Retried bean tacos...yes just beans n some peppers..fkn rockstar...great entertainment watching the cooks pull fresh noodles!!

Terrible: courses arrived at different times (explanation was that there are 3 kitchens so of course we should understand), the advertised shredded chicken came in big pieces including cartilage and a hunk of boiled skin (explanation was that the chef says the skin adds flavor), lots of unnecessary fat in the dishes we ordered, and all this with high prices.  Go somewhere else.

For those of you who do not know. This place serves smaller portions. So you may buy a $13 hot n sour soup and you'll get a bowl. I'm surprised that the fried rice here is $20 and it doesn't have meat. 

I didn't want to eat here cause I got a bad feeling about it. But my friends ordered the hot n sour soup and they ended up returning it because it was too expensive for the price.

Good food and fun ambiance, but very pricey for what you get. My friends and I wanted just some small bites before going out and this place seemed like it would fit the bill. I'd been to Jose Andres' Bazaar in LA so I knew this place would be pricey but probably worth a try. The dishes are actually pretty straightforward and tasty upscale versions of Chinese and Mexican street food. By upscale I mean gold leaf flakes on the dumplings, oyster in a taco, etc. and tiny portions.

Our group got to share:
- Sui Mai (Traditional 6pc  shrimp/pork/water chestnuts/mushrooms/peanuts)
- Dan Dan Mian (hand-cut wheat noodles/spicy pork sauce/peanuts)
- Cctel de Camarones (fresh shrimp/jumbo lump crab meat/tomato/avocado)
- Papas Fritas (fried potatoes with mole poblano/Mexican cream/queso fresco)

And I got for myself in addition:
- Viva China (soft beef tendon/Kumamoto oysters/scallions/Sichuan peppercorn sauce)
- China Paloma (tequila reposado/house-made grapefruit lavender syrup/soda)

I'd have to say my fave item was that Viva China taco! The beef tendon was perfectly crispy/chewy/fatty and the oyster added an extra dimension to the flavors--very good! All told with others ordering a drink of their own everyone's share came to about $35, which is pretty dang pricey for small bites. The service was also decent so I thought it was worth a try, but next time I'll probably save my $$ for other places.

Ok, so my brother has lived in vegas for years and this was one of the first times that I was able to get out there and see him and spend any sort of length of time there as well. Also, his girlfriend just finished culinary school so we were definitely interested in going to a really good restaurant, especially one who's chef is of the ilk of  Jose Andres. The food was better than just "good" the drinks were very tasty, and there was a wide range of selection in regards to how daring one might want to be. The dumplings and the pork buns definitely stand out and the top favorites as well as the guacamole. Most at my table happened to prefer the chinese selections that we had made but really, everything was very very tasty overall. We went for a lunch so that we could walk everything off later and the place was almost empty. Although, we were probably eating much earlier than many who visit vegas. The meal was expensive, but it was well worth it. I will say, that while the drinks were good, I think that they were overpriced based on what you are able to get in the area for less. However, overall, I am a fan and would enjoy going there again for maybe a slightly smaller meal (we definitely over-ordered since we were so excited about all of the options!).

Chinese food is the top ethnic food in America. And Mexican ranks in third. So why not have it both in one place and two in one place! Simply genius!  We sat on the Chinese side of the bar and took our time with drinks. There's so much to pick from and turned to view the place and there was the Dali Lama on a big screen. We ordered Chips & Salsa, Siu Mai, Fried Wonton, Har Gow and the Golden Pigs. Everything was incredibility tasty and fresh. I'll be back.

I know, Chinatown is epic for Asian street food. However I have enjoyed decent dim sum at The Cosmopolitan. 

Wonton soup is not very good. Three stars the smallish dumplings. Five flavorful shrimp and pork are great. 

Noodles? Skinny and resemble Saimen. 

The broth dishwater at best. I added shout, which did little to enhance any savory flavor. 

$18. I'll bring a Cup-of-Noodle next trip.

I was always curious what kind of restaurant this was because of their cool looking art work in front. This restaurant is a fusion of Chinese and Mexican. My girlfriends and I decided to get some tacos to go. I ordered a carnita and a pollo a la parrilla taco. The tacos are really small but it came in these cute brown to go boxes.
